title: Raspberry Pi, tool and camera holder for Tevo Tornado

description.text:
This is a merge of my tool holder with a newly designed Raspberry Pi case and a built in camera holder. It doesn't require any screws to mount to the Tevo Tornado frame (I assume it will work with the CR-10 too but I don't have one so can't confirm).

If you make one please publish a make, it's what keeps me publishing stuff on Thingiverse.

Printer:

Tevo Tornado

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

You shouldn't need supports for anything but the NewCameraHolder2 it has a clip on the side that will need supporting. YMMV
I printed the Pi case with the ball at the very top, I didn't use any supports for that.

A little clean up and assembly

Clean the supports off the NewCameraHolder2 then assemble that part into the hole in NewCameraHolder3. Assemble NewCameraHolder3 onto the ball which is part of the Pi case. It will be tight to get on there but should go on without too much ado. Make sure you support the ball from underneath so that you don't break it off. Once it's assembled you put the Pi into the case, I didn't use anything to hold it in there as it's a pretty snug fit and once your power is plugged in, it shouldn't go anywhere. I didn't print a lid (yet). I may do that but I am working on a cool design to hold it on.

Fusion 360

I used Fusion 360 to design the entire set. I took the tool holder that I had designed previously and merged it into the pi box then designed a camera holder that would attach. I like the double articulation for the camera so that you can position it to see the print head.
I must admit, if I did this over I probably would end up with more consistent wall thicknesses, merging parts means you take the easy way out sometimes ;-)

author: AEPP

description.text:
Thermaltake Matrix computer cases come with a side USB panel. This can be rather annoying if you have your computer below a table and can't properly access the ports. This part provides a replacement solution to this. It changes the mounting point of the USB panel to the front of the case, fitting inside one of the floppy bays.

Assembly

  1. Print the part exactly like in STL. You will need to use some supports for the clips. The orientation is harder to print, but it will provide the best strength.
  2. Remove the front computer case cover and find the USB panel module on the bottom. It looks like a large milky white part.
  3. Unscrew the two screws holding the USB panel module against the cover. Keep the module itself assembled.
  4. Pull all of the cables of the USB panel module out of the computer case's depths.
  5. Push the USB connector ports, FireWire and audio jacks through the holes on the printed panel. The screw holes should align.
  6. Screw the USB panel module into the printed panel using the original screws.
  7. Push the cabling through the floppy bay and finally, push the printed panel into the floppy bay port. It should click into place, much like the original "blank" panels do.

As usual, I am including the Blender source file in case you want to edit it.

Music stand extension

I designed this in Rhino 3D specifically to fit the MANHASSET M48 music stand (used by most Schools and Churches) might fit other stands as well but haven’t tried any others, so print and try it at your own risk.
I have a CR10 3d printer (print bed 12" x 12") and the dimensions of this item are 11" x 7 3/8" so depending on your printer this may or may not work for you.
It’s designed to be used either right or left (universal) to extend either side of the stand.
Obviously you'll need to print 2 of them if you need extra room on both sides like I did.
The extenders that are “designed” for these stands have a rather large “L” at the bottom to match the stand and I needed to be able to transport them in a bag that would not fit the extra L shape, so thus I had to come up with something that would support my music on the stand and fit in my bag at the same time.
Hope this is of some use to folks and happy printing…

title: Tusk Part cooling fan for CR-10

description.text:
Simple direct replacement part for a better part cooling effect.
It is based on the tusk type of part cooling. Two small aluminium tubes are held by a plastic holder that forces all the air of the radial fan into the tubes. There are small holes along the tubes that blow the air down over the printed part.

You need two 30 mm long aluminium tubes of 3 mm diameter. Squeeze one end of each shut and drill holes at 5 mm intervals along the tubes.

The part is simply printed. You will need to use a drill to clean up the 3 mm holes for the tubes. This also allows you to use non-metric tubing if you have trouble getting 3 mm tubes.

Remove the original duct and simply bolt this one on. No need to remove the fan or anything else.

The STL models are checked and optimised. The parts that need a different orientation to print properly are rotated to the preferred printing position.

The Nimble Extruder

With an installed weight of less than 27 grams on your carriage/effector the Zesty Nimble is smallest and lightest extruder you can buy, it has ample torque and can be mounted in multiple orientations.

The Nimble is available from Zesty Technology.

description.text: This is the keychain that we designed for Lexi Lahaie, a fellow FRC student from Onaway, MI.

Printed, not tested yet.
The fan part is uploaded with my other Hexagon AO design

Last summer I decided to see if I could design a lamp that could be built from laser cut parts. I first created the body in Solidworks, then exported the pieces to Rhino where I created the assembly and constellation designs.

I'm calling it a "Constellation Lamp", but this design can actually be whatever you want. I designed the lamp so that the panels are interchangeable; you can make your own sets!

Full instructions can be found on my Instructable

Materials:
-3mm birch plywood (18x24" sheet)
-MR11 bulb
-Socket base (that fits MR11 bulbs)
-Female power jack adapter
-12V power supply adapter
-Super glue (quick drying)
-[Optional] Wood finish

NOTES:
-This was saved in Rhino, and exported to DXF and SVG. If you don't use Rhino, I would recommend trying to import the DXF file first (that one successfully imported for me); I haven't tested the SVG, and it may be missing some parts
-If you use a difference thickness plywood, you will need to modify the grids that connect the pieces
-If you use a different socket base then me, you may need modify the diameter of the laser cut piece that holds it

description.text:
I thought I'd start coming up with uses for various lengths of 12vdc LED tape lighting. A single 50mm x 7.5mm segment of tape costs about $0.07 USD if bought in five-meter 100-segment spools which is less than the cost of the printer filament needed to produce this enclosure. It covers a single 50mm segment of LED tape lighting and provides two holes adjacent to the two sets of solder pads on each end of the tape and does not provide a means of mounting the enclosure except to say that the holes for wires could also be used to affix the light to something.

Once the two halves are assembled the light is locked together meaning you might damage the unit by trying to disassemble it.

Soldering irons melt plastic like butter so the kapton-based LED tape will fuse to the plastic if you solder leads to the tape's pads while it is in the enclosure.

For mounting this enclosure to another surface I'd suggest tape, hot glue, or using one of the wire holes to dangle it from a nail, thumbtack, chain, etc.

These are only the STL files with which I was successfully able to assemble and demonstrate a working LED light. They were designed in OpenSCAD so I will be incorporating this design into a release version of the code, a Thingiverse Customizer and other designs which are forthcoming.

description.text:
A simple docking station for the late 2013 Macbook Pro 13" Retina.

This print has some DIY components to it!
It has a cutout for a LED in the front panel, which is connected to the USB cable.

Cables (charger, displayport and usb) are connected underneath with headless m6 set screws which you have make your own threads on. Holes for it are already pre-made.

The base plate is fastned with two sprints which you have to print as well.

The base plate has a mount hole for the small USB pwr to LED circuit board.

The inside is wrapped with a felt mat to protect the laptop. I designed it to have the sides all wrapped and then fastened with the top piece glued on top.

DISCLAIMER!
This print is untested as of yet so I don't know if I got the laptop profile right. This is why I made the tespProfile file so this can be tested before the big prints.

title: Nest Gen 3 Heating Single Gang Back Plate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have been holding off fitting my Nest Gen 3 as my original heating control box fitted to a single gang socket. The new nest is slightly bigger and I didn't want to have to start drilling holes... So I created this :-)

You will need 2 socket screws (most likely have them from your old control unit). I used 2 x 26mm M3 screws and nyloc nuts. The nuts are pressed into the print to make them captive.

First, press the M3 nuts in, fix the plate to the wall and then fix the nest box using the M3 screw... Easy!

I printed without any support, 70% infill as I want it nice and strong. Printed in PLA and i doubt its going to get hotter then 40 deg's here in the UK.

print_settings.Notes:: I've spilt the four corner posts in half so that they can be printed vertically on most FDM machines with a build height of 150mm or more.

title: Wanhao Duplicator D7 UV Protection Cover

description.text: The D7 comes with a metal cover which isn't exactly light tight, weighs a ton and doesn't allow you to view progress of your ongoing prints. This replacement cover is lightweight and transparent, whilst still protecting the resin from stray UV in the room. And it has a door which means you don't need to remove the lid to top up resin or remove a print.

Printer:

Kossel XL Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I've spilt the four corner posts in half so that they can be printed vertically on most FDM machines with a build height of 150mm or more.

Additional hardware required
  • 3 x 5mm round neodymium magnets (to keep the door closed)
  • 3 x washers/circles of metal (stuck to the door, aligned with the magnets)
  • 3 x 'piano' hinges (25mm wide x 22mm deep)
  • 4 x 3mm thick clear perspex sheets, 160x300x3mm
  • 1 x 3mm thick clear perspex sheet, 177x177x3mm
  • UV Blocking film (I used: SO-AMUV-iSR)
Some links for hardware

Magnets:
https://www.amazon.co.uk/Magnet-Expert%C2%AE-5mm-thick-Neodymium/dp/B00TACMMP0/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1517083355&sr=8-2&keywords=neodymium+magnets+5mm

Washers:
https://www.amazon.co.uk/Stainless-Steel-Form-Flat-Washers/dp/B00KB3KYWU/ref=sr_1_13?s=diy&ie=UTF8&qid=1517083458&sr=1-13&keywords=5mm+washers

Hinges:
https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00X2XNXEM/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

UV Film:
http://www.stockfilms.co.uk/architectural-window-film/specialist-window-film-internal/amber-uv-control

Perspex:
http://www.perspexsheet.uk/perspex-clear/

Assembly

Before starting, install your UV film onto the perspex sheets, Your choice of UV film is up to you of course, but I went for stuff rated up to the 500nm range to protect the resin left in the vat when the printer isn't in use, and also from giving my eyeballs a sunburn while the D7 does it's thing. The SO-AMUV-iSR film isn't cheap - it cost me around £60 for 1.6x2m of the stuff, but if you're going to do this project, why not do it properly? :)

It's critical to have the perspex extremely clean when you apply the film as it sticks very quickly when the water on the surface is displaced, and is difficult to move without creasing or tearing it, and any debris or dust is likely going to stay if it finds its way under the film! Obviously, follow manufacturers instructions on fitting. Perspex isn't an idea surface for films, and you will likely get bubbles forming after a few days, but these can be smoothed out, and haven't reappeared on mine.

Once you have the perspex covered and the film trimmed in, assemble the four posts, noting that the two identical ones are for the rear (print two each of the rear parts!), on the front posts the hinge cut-outs go to the right and the holes for the magnets to the left (facing the case).

Carefully push the perspex into the gooves, ensuring that the bottom of the sheet is parallel with the bottom of each post. Also, install with the UV film facing INTO the box to help protect it from external knocks.

Once you have three sides fitted, loose fit the top sheet and install three top braces into the slots between posts, ensuring that the bottom of the braces are in front of the perspex. The braces should hold the top sheet in place, however you might want to use a drop of superglue on the top of each post to ensure it doesn't move.

Install your magnets into the left hand side post with glue or epoxy.

Rest the door panel (UV film side inwards) and mark where the magnets are - glue washers or metal disks on the inside of the door to match up with the magnets.

Flip the door over and superglue/epoxy the handle in place.

Glue the top-brace part onto the top of the door. This is the brace with the logo.

Install the hinges, and attach to the door (I again used epoxy for this.

Enjoy watching your prints!

title: Stupid Tall and Strong Fang for CR10 with 5015 and 40mm fan

description.text:
This is the " Stupid Tall and Strong Fang" made for the cr10 to be used with 5015 part fan and 40mm cooling fan.
The idea behind this is i wanted a Really rigid, strong and stable Fang to be used with a Noctua 40mm fan, and that at the same time would allow great visibility of the nozzle

This is a remix from the from the " cr-10 fang fan mod " from chris bibby on Myminifactory adapted to the "CR-10 Heavy Duty customisable modular e3D V6 mount "

The fang can be printed like a regular fang, with or without supports as you prefer, but i printed with no supports and came out perfect.

The X carriage Mount needs to be printed as it is oriented, and it DOES need supports!

The best materials would be ABS or petg, but i guess pla could hold just fine.

For the Hardware you will need:
To mount the x carriage Mount to the x carriage: 2x M3 6mm
To lock the e3d in place: 2x M3 30mm + 2 M3 Nuts
To attach the fang: 2x M3 10mm
To connect the 5015fan to the fang: 1x M3 20mm
To attach the 40mm fan to the duct: 4x M3 20mm ( you could use only 2)

For more informations about the "heavy duty modular mount" here is the link to the page with detailed instructions: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2494642
Link for the Fang Mod from Chris Bibby on Myminifactory: https://www.myminifactory.com/object/cr-10-fang-fan-mod-53825

Hope you will like it and that this will satisfy your crave for a decent fang for your creality and e3d v6 ( clone or not :P )

Good prints!

P.S. Tips are always appreciated :) http://paypal.me/neverstopseeking

author: varg86

description.text:
Slimmer String "Climbing" Christmas Tree is based on this thing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1858628.

My mother found the aforementioned thing and wanted me to print a couple for my nieces. I liked it but decided to tinker with it.

Changes made:

  • Made the tree slimmer.
  • Made the tree split in 1/2 instead of using a cover on one end.
  • Made the Star topper more 3D-ish.
  • Changed the orientation of the climbing mechanisms spool.
  • Enclosed the spool in a small case (easier to manage and less likely to tangle).
  • Increased some tolerances.
  • Added bearings to make it smoother (Optional).

Requires embroidery floss.

Optionally you can use a couple of bearing to make the climbing mechanism smoother. I had some small bearings I ordered in the wrong size laying around and decided to use them. There is a separate STL for a spool case and spool wheals designed to fit 4x8x3mm flanged bearings. (You'll need two).

Most of the instructions are the same, so I copied them from the original thing and modified as necessary.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

20%

Notes:

4 Solid Layers top and bottom, 3 perimeters.
Only the Star needs supports, and only for the portion that is inserted into the top of the tree.

Parts I Purchased

1) Embroidery floss (super center, sewing shop, Amazon, etc). Sewing thread is too thin, and standard cotton string is too large and frays.
2) (OPTIONAL) 4x8x3mm Flanged ball bearings. (Amazon)

Printing

Print 2 "RingPull.stl", then 1 of each of the others.
Don't print the ExplodedAssembly.stl (obviously).
If you plan to use bearings print the "_ForBearings.stl" and omit their respective non bearing file.
If you don't plan to use the bearings then omit the "_ForBearings.stl" parts.

Assembly

Prior to assembly, test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, sanding mayl be required.

Assemble as per "ExplodedAssembly.stl".
General assembly order:

  1. Press Center spool onto the larger spool end.

  2. Press smaller spool onto the pieces assembled in step 1.

  3. Press small axle part onto other side of the larger spool.

  4. Cut two 24"-36" lengths of embroidery floss, and tie a knot into one end of each piece.
    May require a double knot.

  5. Starting with the unknotted end, thread the embroidery floss into the small hole on the larger spool starting from the flat side, then pull it all the way through until the knot sits inside the hole. Secure the knot in the hole using cyanoacrylate glue.

  6. Repeat previous step with the smaller spool.

  7. Wind the embroidery thread onto the spools in opposite directions. On the large spool, leave about 4" of embroidery thread unwound, the small spool about 10" of embroidery thread unwound.

  8. Optional insert one bearing into each side of the spool case.

  9. Pass the thread from one spool through the hole in one half of the spool case and place spool into case making sure the thread isn't caught.

  10. Pass thread from the other spool through the hole in the second half of the spool case and then snap the two halves together. You should be able to pick up the mechanism and check that it works at this point. You'll need to be a little careful, but it should snap together pretty securely.

  11. Place the spool case in the bottom half of tree with the longer thread going laying across the opening at the top of the tree and the smaller length of thread across the opening at the bottom.

  12. Snap the top tree half onto the bottom half. (optionally add some glue in a few spots along the edges that snap together)

  13. Slide the thread form the top through the hole in the star and press the star onto the top of the tree. (optionally add a little glue to the part of the star that slides into the tree)

  14. Tie a ring onto each thread.

  15. Pick the entire assemble up by the rings, the upper ring on top. Pulling either ring will cause String Climbing Christmas Tree to climb the embroidery floss. Allowing the embroidery floss to go slack will allow gravity to return String Climbing Christmas Tree to the lower ring.

This small assembly makes it possible to maintain a SMD component plated on the printed circuit while it is soldered.

To realize this assembly, it is necessary, in addition to two parts printed in 3D:

  • A small spring: I got it on an old clothespin
  • A needle: type “needle smd” into a search engine.
  • M4 screw / nut

It’s a simple montage, inspired by this one: SMD solder holder I found the idea very good, but I wanted to improve 2 points:

  • An impression without support
  • Simplify editing by removing the gallows.
  • And by the way, also to use a model of spring and needle that I recovered

You will need this for ONE drawer:

  • 16 pcs x 5 mm M4 thread inserts (Hardware store or Ebay)
  • 16 pcs x min 15 mm long wood screws
  • 16 pcs x 6 mm M4 screws (Hardware store or Ebay)
  • 4 pcs x "Rill" caster wheels from Ikea (or something similar that fits)
  • Screw driver/ hex key
  1. Push the threaded inserts into the plastic. I use a soldering iron for this, heat it up and just push the inserts into the plastic. Works really well. Cut of any excess plastic to make the surface as flat as possible. Some plastic might seep into the thread from the bottom, drill or cut it away.
  2. Screw the wheels onto the brackets.
  3. Attach a bracket in each corner of the drawer's frame and secure them with the wood screws.

print_settings.Notes:: I used 3 perimeters

description.text: Very simple basic extruder calibration helper for 1.75 mm filament printers.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I used 3 perimeters

Why I made it?

I was sick and tired to use calipers over and over again with extrusion check. It was inconvenient and hardly fit to the extruder head. As a simplification I designed this simple tool to get rid of calipers ;-)
This helper is intended to be used for basic extruder calibration only. More advanced one needs to be done via specially designed and printed calibration objects.
However this calibration is good enough in the most of cases or as a first step if higher precision is needed.

How to use?

It is very easy to use. Just

  • snap the filament
  • mark the top
  • extrude
  • check
  • compute ratio
  • adjust if needed
Snap the helper tightly next to the top of the extruder body. Filament should snap into. There are 2 latches at the top and bottom of the helper. Mark the top point of the helper with a marker. Direct printer top extrude 100mm filament and check the mark on the filament. If extrusion is accurate after extrusion of 100mm the mark should be aligned with top of the extruder body. Extrusion

Extrusion can be done via following gcode command
G1 X100.0
It should extrude 100 mm of filament

Another option is extrude via OctoPrint control tab or directly via control panel of the printer.

Ration computation

After the print distance between the mark and top of the extruder body needs to be computed.

There are 3 possibilities

  1. Calibration is correct - The marking is fully aligned with the top of the extruder body. No further action is needed.
  2. Over extruded - The marking is inside of the extruder body. Another calibration run is needed with shorter extrusion. (<100) repeat until calibration is correct
  3. Under extruded - The marking is above the extruder body. ANother calibration run is needed with longer extrusion. (>100) repeat until calibration is correct

You can use scale on the calibrator to estimate required extrusion change.

Then compute calibration correction ratio as a ratio between real extrusion and 100.
realExtrusion / 100

Number should be >1 for under extrusion and <1 for over extrusion.
This number should be used to adjust (multiply) either firmware default setting or slicer extrusion ratio.

Detailed description how is of scope of this model. You can find them other tutorials.

author: askenar

description.text: External drive rack

This rack holds external hard drives. Transferring files can require hours and this keeps them out of my way. I don't like laying the warm drives atop one another, plus they require less space when standing on edge. Slots are sized to fit my thickest drive, a WD 1 terabyte (the short one in front), with a bit of room to spare. Almost all my tools and machines are SAE/Imperial so I prefer that system but for the sake of international peace and tranquility this is a metric version...basically just scaled my original 3.5x3.5x2 inch STL up to ~89x89x53 "Blender units".
Afinia print software can't tell the difference between them but evidently some others can. 80 minutes, 34 grams ABS using Afinia default settings (0.30mm Z, medium speed with a raft).

title: Simple Pen Stand for Four Pens

description.text:
While waiting for inspiration for a fancy pen stand for my fountain pens, I modelled this simple oval shape to keep them organized on my desktop. It's a bit boring, but functional.

The hole sizes are specific to the pens I'm putting in them - so there will be some incongruities with whatever writing implements you wish to organize, however the odds are good that you'll have pens of some sort lying about that will fit in some spots.

There is a little bump indicator so you remember which end is the front on the otherwise symmetrical object. It helps for remembering where your favourite pen fits best.

If you load the STL into a tool of your choice, you could of course adjust the hole sizes to your preference.

The fountain pens on display in the photo, back to front are a no-name calligraphy pen (10.5mm), a Japanese Riviere fountain pen (8.7mm), a Waterman Maestro (8.5mm), and a Mont Blanc (9mm hole).

Slight size differences change how straight the pen sits in the hole.

remixed_from.title: Simple Anti Z Wobble for Anet A8

title: Anet A8 Anti Z-Wobble for use with dampers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
this is intended for use with my Anet A8 Z motor mount for use with motor damper https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2703469

this thing remixes 2 items.
1) Simple Anti Z Wobble for Anet A8 by sicksubie (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2121017) was shortened by 3 millimeters (it is not included in the photo, the photo is using the original item)
2) Anet A8 Anti Z-Wobble by Tissat has its height doubled, but took a while because i did not want to remove any of the chamfers or bevels, but still wanted it to mount using the same screw as the original part, don't worry, all those lines in the preview are too small to print.

to complete the build you will need
two 608 bearings.
2 "short Simple Anti Z Wobble for Anet A8"
1 "tall anti z wobble - left"
1 "tall anti z wobble - right"

bearings:
i personally recommend a 10 pack because they will come in a storage tube and you will eventually use them.

10 packs on ebay (note the following 3 links are ebay referral links, if you purchase them i will receive a small portion of the purchase, doing so would make me happy and encourage me to keep up making things and remixes, i shortened them using tinyurl because they were extremely long)
ships from china http://tinyurl.com/y732aal2
i believe these are rubber seals (note the title says metal shield, but the photo shows rubber seals.and the descriptions says "red" (and metal shields are not usually painted.)

the following are US shipping
with metal shield http://tinyurl.com/y8uw2a6v
with rubber seal http://tinyurl.com/y7ffmqv3

you will need a total of 4 prints
2 "short Simple Anti Z Wobble for Anet A8"
1 "tall anti z wobble - left"
1 "tall anti z wobble - right"

Printer:

anet a8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

the Simple Anti Z Wobble for Anet A8 by sicksubie was printed in inland black ABS and is slightly tight, which is perfect for this. so i recommend printing this part in ABS.

the tall Anet A8 Anti Z-Wobble was printed in inland black PLA ,and fits perfectly, so i recommend printing this in PLA.
the bearing fit with a few taps with my hammer and the rod fit once i cleaned up the inside.
all items are already oriented for printing. just drop into your slicer and slice em up

the holes should be a little tight, but with a little force you should be able to get the rod and bearing in.

if the fit is a little too tight check for any "pimples" and strings, and remove them.
if it's still tight check for a elephant's foot (wide first layer) and remove the inside edges
and if it's still too tight, sand them down little by little
if you do use a hammer use light taps, not heavy swings, because you do not want to mushroom one end of either rod

i personally use a deburring tool i bought from home depot to remove the elephant's foot.
but heres some similar tool off ebay (using more referral links)
ships from china http://tinyurl.com/y87l5dna
ships from US http://tinyurl.com/yb6bq6wr.
note the one from the US is over $25!!!
so i recommend going and getting the exact same tool (except for the colors) from home depot, but costs $6.78 (plus tax)
it includes the handle, and 2 blades, and the blades get stored in the handle.
https://www.homedepot.com/p/HDX-Deburring-Tool-HDX090/204218603

this tool is a little strange to use in the beginning (because you need to go against the habit of holding the blade at a angle), but has quickly become my go to tool for removing elephant's foot.

Ich hatte noch ein 20 mm Rohr rum liegen .Das kann man wenn man einfach einhängen . Funkktioniert für mich sehr gut

I wanted to try scanning in some objects using a series of pictures. After playing around I soon found it works much better if you carefully control the angle of each shot. To that end I printed up a quick and dirty turntable. It has 50 stops per rotation (lining up with the 50 picture limit on some programs). I included a couple of scanned objects as examples.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

I used 0.2 with a 0.3mm nozzle

Infill:

N/A

Assembly:

I hot-glued the base to a piece of plywood and the wheel to a piece of foamboard. Lay the wheel on top and make sure to engage the ratchet. I had painted the top white, but later found out it should actually have a good pattern to it so the software can triangulate on it better.

Use:

Place the object to be scanned in the center of the turntable and position your camera on a tripod pointed down at about 30 degrees. Snap a picture and advance the turntable 1 notch until you get a full 360 degree view.

I first tried the open source Regard3D (http://www.regard3d.org/index.php). While this did work, it had many false starts and a lot of post editing to clean things up.

I then tried 3DF Zephyr (30-day trial) which worked much better. It identified the object on the first try and needed only about 10 minutes of cleanup.

Finally I tried Recap-Photo. This was by far the best. Upload your photos, drink a beer and download an almost perfect model.Videos made from the scanned in 3D Models are here: https://youtu.be/ls2AXYDMsus and here: https://youtu.be/kqfiz2cBTBM

Recap is an expensive program, but if you enjoy 3D printing and problem solving, I would highly encourage you to check out the FIRST Robotics organization (https://www.firstinspires.org/), find a local school or team in need of mentors and help them out. Along the way you can pick up a free educational account from AutoDesk that includes all their software packages.

comments.text:
Awesome idea, thanks!!

comments.text: See the bottom of the description. I got three of them to work, but AutoDesk Recap was by far the easiest. I was surprised by the results also, look at the second video on a 4K monitor if you can.

description.text:
2018 update:
Items needed:

  • 16 mm aluminum tube (you have to drill it an 8 mm hole)
  • V3 Microswitch SPDT 16a Micro Switch (http://www.ebay.es/itm/V3-Microswitch-SPDT-16A-Micro-Switch/251827572523?hash=item3aa217cf2b:m:mONdUDFbmsgXjdcCSmAGbFg)
  • Two bolts (3x30 mm) with 2 nuts.
  • One bolt (8x50 mm) with 1 nut.
  • One spring (i bought one from a chinese store, cut it and left 3 rings of it).
  • One Digispark Usb ATTINY85 board (to emulate a key for our handbrake).
    I bought this one: http://digistump.com/products/1 (from aliexpress).
  • Two wires.

Tools needed:
-Soldering Iron: You'll have to solder the P0 pin and GND to your Switch.
-Dremel alike tool.
-Driller (to make an 8 mm hole to our tube).
-Micro usb cable.

Software needed:
-Arduino IDE (https://www.arduino.cc/en/main/software).
You'll have to install the trinket keyboard library's and the Attiny85 board drivers (because Arduino IDE have to recognise the board).
-Digistump digispark drivers (https://digistump.com/wiki/digispark/tutorials/connecting).
-Handbrake board code (this code enables the board to push the COMMA keyboard button mapped to our switch).
Handbrake code download: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ueVhz8GHW2HozKdMkt_V-fGilqvFoX9U/view?usp=sharing

The attiny85 hardcase is optional. Also you can change the way you map your handbrake switch. In 2015 i used and old Usb Joystick, but this time i used an Arduino board clone).

Once you have completed your DIY handbrake you'll have to screw it to your shifter.

title: Peine maquina de pelar 12 mm (Comb peeling machine 12 mm?)

description.text:
Se nos rompió el peine de la maquina de pelar que más utilizamos y aunque teníamos otros de otras maquinas, decidí, al ver otros por esta web, de diseñarlo. El que veis en la imagen tiene un pequeño defecto, el cual hace que se salga de la maquina pero en los ficheros ya está arreglado, le he agrandado la pieza que hace el clic en la parte posterior. Este como era de prueba lo hice a 0.3 de resolución, pero para que quede más fino ponerle 0.2.
O dejo el archivo Freecad para que podáis adaptarlo a vuestra maquina.

Traduccion Google:
We broke the comb of the machine that most used peel and although we had other machines, I decided, to see others on this website, to design it. The one you see in the image has a small defect, which makes it leave the machine but in the files is already fixed, I have enlarged the piece that makes the click on the back. This was as a test I did it at 0.3 of resolution, but to make it thinner to put it 0.2.
Or I leave the Freecad file so that you can adapt it to your machine.

author: Mag-net

description.text:
This is a collection of the different Death Star wall panels that were seen in the Star Wars movies. Made to go with 1:12 scale action figures to enhance a collector's display. I haven't tested these files yet, so feel free to give them a go and let me know how they work out!

The files are made for easy printing. Some partial gluing and assembly is required.

I have included different "connector" types to give more flexibility to display options (90°, 45° and 180°) for more dynamic wall arrangements. Also, you will notice an "outside corner endpiece" file, this is made up of three different components (two plugs and corner splice" these files are intended for creating an outside corner condition.

DS Wall 07 has some parts that need to be glued to the back (cavity caps top and bottom) in order to fill in the vent holes.

Feedback is greatly appreciated! Please be sure to give a shout out via IG (isntagram) and FB (Facebook) @figureworkscustoms if you end up printing or offering these as goods, I would love to see how these turn out.

More goods to come!

Happy printing!! :D

  • UPDATE (04 Feb '18) : I have added two more wall design variations, feel free to have a look!

  • UPDATE (09 Feb '18) : Modified back structure to allow for vertical and horizontal connections of the modular walls. Also, added "Base Extender" and "Back Support" files to help hold the wall up laterally. The base extender was designed to allow weights to be added on top.

Software Used

Designed using Rhinoceros 3D

• Modeling
  • Scale
  • Proportion
  • Tolerances
  • Desing

A 1/5 scale copy of a wicker basket made with Autodesk's ReCap Photo and a simulated "weaved" basket made with OpenSCAD. They could serve as desk containers.

The weaved basket is based on "Parametric Boxes Made of Hexagons" - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1255039 - The hexagons were changed into squares and handles added. Changes to the code are noted in "weaved_basket.scad".

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

The weaved pattern starts as an array of squares placed on a hexagonal lattice. The squares are made three dimensional and removed from a side of the box leaving square holes. The original square array is duplicated and offset by translations along x and y. Again the squares are made three dimensional and removed from a box side to create a second version. The two versions are added together to form the pattern. It apparently has cmm symmetry.

print_settings.Notes:: I turned this right side up in my slicer, as I figured the wheels running along the layers would cause it to delaminate over time. The resolution was left they way it is in my default profile, and the "stair step" effect on the incline from printing right side up isn't noticeable (I was worried it would sound like a skateboard going over a sidewalk). I used a 50% infill as the wardrobe doors are pretty heavy, so I figured this would help these last longer (and they're such small parts, it wouldn't make a huge difference to print time or filament usage anyway).

title: Roller Wedge for a Spaceslide wardrobe door
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
We have a few built in wardrobes that are made by a company called Spaceslide. They have these little wedges (similar to this object) in the bottom rails that the wheels of the doors ride up on to and sit in to keep them from being too easily nudged aside. We were missing one on the middle door, and our cat was pushing open the wardrobe doors at ridiculous hours and the dog would start barking at her. Here's hoping these will get us a more peaceful night's sleep!

This was my first attempt at designing something in Fusion 360, so I was quite surprised when I printed them out and they seem to work! I stuck it down with a bit of rolled up masking tape for now, which seems to add just enough friction to keep it in place.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

The resolution was left they way it is in my default profile, and the "stair step" effect on the incline from printing right side up isn't noticeable (I was worried it would sound like a skateboard going over a sidewalk). I used a 50% infill as the wardrobe doors are pretty heavy, so I figured this would help these last longer (and they're such small parts, it wouldn't make a huge difference to print time or filament usage anyway).

remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 MK2 Y Chassis Bearing Straps & Integrated Bushings

title: P3Steel Yaxis PLA bushing with integrated flange

description.text: I remixed Fiveangle"s bushings to fit my P3Steel v2.5 Y carriage. My cheap chinese linear bearings were failing and my Misumi replacements hadn't yet arrived. I only changed the flanges and hole spacing to fit the P3Steel. I made no changes to the actual bushing. I intended to attach them to the carriage with 3mm screws and locknuts but as I tightend the screws the bushings would start to bind. With nothing to lose I decided to try attaching them with zip ties through the holes and around the bushing. This turned out to work well. My new bearings and smooth rods from Misumi have arrived but these are working well so I see no reason to replace them for now. I intend to run them just to see how well they hold up.

comments.text: as I tightend the screws the bushings would start to bind.
comments.author: fiveangle

comments.text: Thinking more, I wonder if using bolts to mount the bushings on one side, then using zip-ties for the other side would allow the one side to "float" a little -- preventing binding -- but still keep the bed perfectly located by the one side ?  If you try it, let us know how it goes.
comments.author: fiveangle

comments.text: Thanks for the comments and the great design Fiveangle. I have no doubt that you are spot on regarding the misalignment of my Y axis smooth rods. Especially since tensioning the Y axis belt causes the front frame plate to bow. This bow would result in the rod ends moving closer together at the front. One would think that the front and back plates might bow the same amount but that doesn't appear to be true. The PLA bushings are working very well. My only concern at this point is how long they might last. Are the MK2 printers that you mentioned  running for about a year on the original set of PLA bushings? If so that is encouraging. I printed mine with Hatchbox black PLA since that is what I had available. I wonder if  filament from other brands would perform differently. I may give your idea about screws on one side a try. Although the zip ties seem to be working fine. If I do try it I will let you know. Thanks,
comments.author: fiveangle

description.text:
I know this isn't the first Anet A8 Power Supply Cover, but it's the one I use.

I was temporarily using an Anet A8 20A PSU when the ATX PSU I had modified for my Printerbot Simple Metal died.

When the new replacement 30A PSU arrived, I decided to make a cover for it (I don't want the power connectors exposed). I liked the design so much that with a slight modification to fit the Anet A8 PSU, I reused the same design.

The switch is repurposed from a dead ATX PSU and is rated at 10A.

Just a note, you will have to drill and tap a hole on the left side of your PSU to secure this cover.

title: 1-to-4 HDD Stackable Raspberry NAS with PSU v1

description.text:
Designer : Blender
Slicer : Slic3r
Printer : Creality 3D CR-10
Material : PLA Optimus 1.75 White (filament-abs.fr)

You should print the v2 instead : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2784565

Compact Stackable Raspberry NAS with PSU and between 1 and 4 hotplug HDD

IMPORTANT

I made it, but I am not fully happy of it because of too much post-printing. I began a v2 with tradoffs on the HDD size and on the power rail.

The lower bullet connector holes are very tight and need heated to insert the terminals.
The bullet connectors are (too) hard to insert/remove from the stack
It does the job, but I'm not really happy with the ease of use/assembly. I'll probably make a v2.

Goal

A small NAS using a Raspberry, with 4 HDD and a power supply, to save energy and space. It does not have to be lightining fast for my home needs (backups, photos/movies/music repository, ...)

Design constraints

I currently use a small standard PC with 2x1TB HDD in RAID as a storage for backups with RSync. This is an overkill. I want to upgrade the usage with OpenMediaVault (http://www.openmediavault.org/) to store

  • my backups (RSync and/or Rsnapshot,
  • my movies (for XBMC/Kodi),
  • my music (for XBMC/Kodi),
  • a MacBook Air's timemachine backups.

I want to optimize the energy+space vs usage ration with :

  • Dedicated sized Power Suply Unit
  • Raspberry Pi 2 (no need for Wifi, Ethernet cable sharing the USB bus is fine)
  • 4x 1TB HDD (SSD would be better, but far too expensive for this project and not justified)

I don't want to power the HDD from the RPi USB sockets, I chose to Double USB to SATA cable adaptor to get power directly from the PSU to the HDD
I don't want to power the RPi from its side USB power socket (bad location, power supposed clean, ... I'll power the RPi from the GPIO pins
I wont use any kind of UPS (in case of power failure, no client will connect) and it would be difficult to design such an UPS for the RPi and 4 spinning disks. I'll work at the software layer to make it robust against unexpected poweroff.
I want to be able to hotplug/unplug HDDs easily, without a tray
I want to be able to mout/unmount the stack to scale up/down using few screws and with backplane power rail connectors
I want to be able to insert/remove the RPi SD card without unmounting anything
The HDD bay needs to be able to receive different 2.5 HDD form factor (L=100mm, W=700mm H=9.5,12.5,17.19mm)
I still hate to remove and clean support material from my printings... The design should be supportless ! ;)

Bill Of Material :

  • Power cord
  • micro power switch 250V/3A : https://www.banggood.com/20pcs-250V-3A-Mini-Boat-Rocker-Switch-2-Pin-Plastic-Button-ONOff-SPST-p-1044250.html
  • Generic Power Supply Unit AC 110-220V To DC 5V 6A 30W : https://www.banggood.com/AC-85-265V-to-DC-5V-6A-30W-Switch-Power-Supply-for-Car-LED-Strip-Lights-p-967013.html
  • Raspberry Pi 2
  • Raspberry Pi 2/3 Copper Heat Sink Heat Sink https://www.banggood.com/Raspberry-Pi-23-Copper-Heat-Sink-Heatsink-With-3M-Special-Thermal-Cooling-Paste-p-1045808.html
  • SD card
  • 4x 1TB HDD : https://www.ldlc.com/fiche/PB00235600.html
  • 4x Double USB to SATA cable adapter : https://www.banggood.com/Double-USB-2_0-Adapter-Cable-715pin-Male-to-Male-for-Laptop-2_5HDD-Hard-Disk-Drive-p-1026866.html
  • M3 6mm screws (the screws used in computers to secure all the parts together)
  • 10 bullet connector pairs : https://www.banggood.com/Wholesale-10x-3_5mm-Gold-Bullet-Banana-Connector-Plug-For-ESC-Battery-Motor-p-51435.html?rmmds=search

Printing

Before printing

You might need :

  • to check and adjust the size and location of the screw holes for the PSU
  • to check and adjust the size and location of the screw holes and walls for the SATA-USB PCB adaptors depending on yours
  • to check and adjust the size of the bullet terminals (both length and width)
    Even if you buy the same references from the same supplier, the item can change, sometimes. ;)

Power supply level (at the bottom for the stability):

  • Printed on CR-10, with PLA in 7 hours and 6 minutes (approx 66g of PLA)
  • Nozzle 0.4mm
  • first layer 0.375 mm @ 195°C/75°C, other layers: 0.2 mm @ 190°C/70°C
  • 3 top layers, 3 bottom layers, 3 perimeters
  • Infill : 20% honeycomb
  • Skirt suggested, Brim recommended, no support
  • PSU mounted with 2xM3 screws
  • Added a mini-power switch

HDD level (between 1 and 4 times):

  • Printed on CR-10, with PLA in 3 hours and 53 minutes (approx. 51g of PLA)
  • Nozzle 0.4mm
  • first layer 0.375 mm @ 195°C/75°C, other layers: 0.2 mm @ 190°C/70°C
  • 3 top layers, 3 bottom layers, 3 perimeters
  • Infill : 20% honeycomb
  • Skirt suggested, Brim recommended, no support

RPi level

  • Printed on CR-10, with PLA in 3 hours and few minutes
  • Nozzle 0.4mm
  • first layer 0.375 mm @ 195°C/75°C, other layers: 0.2 mm @ 190°C/70°C
  • 3 top layers, 3 bottom layers, 3 perimeters
  • Infill : 20% honeycomb
  • Skirt suggested, Brim recommended, no support

Cover layer

  • Printed on CR-10, with PLA in 3 hours and 53 minutes (approx. 51g of PLA)
  • Nozzle 0.4mm
  • first layer 0.375 mm @ 195°C/75°C, other layers: 0.2 mm @ 190°C/70°C
  • 0 top layers, 0 bottom layers, 5 perimeters
  • Infill : 20% honeycomb
  • Skirt suggested, Brim recommended, no support

Assembly

Power Supply

Pass the power cord through the front small hole, connect the negative to the N terminal on the PSU,
Pass the positive (brown or red) through the front switch hole (from inside to outside) and connect it to one of the switch terminals.
Connect the second switch terminal to the L terminal on the PSU (back through the switch hole) from outside to inside.
Solder a blue wire to one of the bullet, and a red wire to the other one.
Pass the blue wire from outside to insinde through the internal power stack hole and push the bullet in the hole (you can force or heat to make it pass, and use hot glue to secure it).
Pass the red wire from outside to insinde through the external power stack hole and push the bullet in the hole (you can force or heat to make it pass, and use hot glue to secure it).
Connect the blue wire to the negative terminal on the PSU and the red wire to the positive one.
Finally, use 2xM3 4mm sscrewws to secure the PSU on the bottom plate.
You can test that you don't have any shortcut with a volt metter.
Connect a volt metter (set to more than 6V) to the bullets, the power cord to the main, and switch on the switch. The LED should light up.
Use a screw driver to adjust the voltage somewhere between 5 and 5.2V using the small tuning screw on the PSU, near the LED.
Hint: you can secure the bullet terminals in their holes using a piece of PLA/ABS from the skirt/brim/raft with your soldering/reworking station to lock the bullet in the hole.

HDD levels

Unmount the SATA plug adaptor (clipsed) to extract the PCB
solder a red wire on a male bullet
solder a red wire on a female bullet
solder a blue wire on a male bullet
solder a blue wire on a female bullet
pass the male red wire from outside to inside in the external bottom hole
pass the male blue wire from outside to inside in the internal bottom hole
add the male red wire to the female red bullet by soldering it
add the male blue wire to the female blue bullet by soldering it
push the female bullets in their hole, eventually securing them with hot glue or melted PLA/ABS
solder the red wire in place of the red wire (on one side) on the PCB
solder the blue wire in place of the black (on hte other side) wire on the PCB
secure and insulate as you want (cutting different length, using electric tape, using heat shrink tubes, ...) the red and black original wires
place the PCB on the tray with the SATA connector at the bottom and secure it with 2 M2 2/3/4mm screws
Hint : use your soldering iron tip to heat each of the bullets, one by one, to adjust their position and lock them in the ABS/PLA
Hint : Hotglue under the PCB to secure it more than with the 2 M2 screws only
Hint : Hot glue all around the bullet connectors
Hint : gently pre and post heat the hot glue with hot air (reworking station or air gun

RPI level

solder a red wire on a male bullet
solder a blue wire on a male bullet
pass the male red wire from outside to inside in the external bottom hole
pass the male blue wire from outside to inside in the internal bottom hole
crimp a dupont connector on the red wire
crimp a dupont connector on the blue wire
connect the red wire to the second pin and the blue wire to the third pin of the RPi GPIO (double check the pinout, you can frie your RPi)
Connect the USB plugs and the network.

Possible improvements:

  • Add status LED (Power)
  • Add status LED (System starting/started/stopping/stopped blink/loadHeartBeat/blinking/off)
  • Add status LED (OMV process stopped/starting/started no process=off, process but no http=blink, process and http=on)
  • Add an high voltage fuse
  • Add a graceful reboot/shutdown GPIO push button (short/long press)
  • Redesign the HDD level with a tray

remixed_from.title: CR-10 Keenovo Bed Clip and Wire Strain Relief

description.text:
This is a remix of Dhien2's stain relief. This design followed that design concept. Mine however is designed to mount onto 1/4" glass with a BuildTak print surface. I have my glass bed slid back off the Y's metal platform plate around an inch. This allow's the EZABL's probing pattern to be more centered on the Y axis of the glass. This stays mounted by it's press-on fit. It's not super crazy snug. It's doesn't have to be. It does fit well though. Other then being a strain relief for the cables, it also helps prevent the cables from snagging on the Y motor. Fluke accidents happen sometimes but this helps protect against that.

Note: This part does NOT grab both the metal mounting platform plate and the glass. ONLY the 1/4" glass and BuildTak surface. With the next few days I'll design the other one.

Print this in ABS.

eBus is a telegram based protocol used by some boiler brand like Vaillant, Wolf.

This is an accessory to the Prusa Y-axis belt tensioner here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10274
Some setups also use this tensioning mechanism for the X-axis.
The trouble is that if you over-tighten the tensioning M3 bolt (or simply over time) the screw will poke all the way through the timing belt and ruin it. This piece acts like a padding and evenly distributes the tension across the belt surface.

Print this on your 3D printer with a high fill ratio so that the M3 bolt doesn't bore through the plastic.
I have not built this yet, but will post pictures as soon as I do. Please try it in the meanwhile and let me know what you think.
Thanks!

description.text:
This thing gives your bathroom tissue roll a smooth run.
This is to be used with roll sticks whose diameter are smaller than the roll hole. These cap ends make the axe fit inside them so when you pull the paper out the hole roll is stable and runs smooth.
The caps included have both different internal diameters. As you can see in the pictures the stick I made this for has different diameters on both ends. Internal diameter for the larger is 24.20 mm and 21 mm for the smaller one.
The caps are strong but thin it is easy to sand them to measure so it fit other larger sticks if needed.
Whenever possible install them on new unused rolls. Already used roll holes are usually out of shape and then its more difficult to keep the caps in.

About the .prp file included in the package

The .prp file included with the package is the complete package in ProjectRoom format. You can import this project directly into your projects database by using ProjectRoom import function. More about this at ProjectRoom website. http://www.peekglass.com/projectroom

Important: Print with supports! The rail ends have an overhang. The design includes a pad for the supports, which ensures that the supports stick well to the printer bed, and also help with breaking them off easily. Make sure the supports break off cleanly, otherwise the tracks won't snap together properly. I recommend using "High Quality" or "Detailed" mode.

Prints well with either PLA or ABS. If you have a smaller print bed, try rotating the pieces 30 or 45 degrees to make them fit.

A set of train tracks compatible with LEGO battery powered trains. My goal was to have more flexibility, so I designed curved pieces in different radii and length, shorter straight pieces, and a 67.5 degree crossing.

  • Straight tracks are identified by number of ties.
  • Curved track pieces are identified by radios in LEGO dots and number of ties.
  • Crossing are identified by the crossing angle.

For the pieces which match standard LEGO train elements, it is probably more economical to just buy them, unless you buy your filament on sale, or have some filament left that you just want to finsh.

A good source of information about LEGO track geometry is here:
http://l-gauge.org/wiki/index.php/Welcome_to_L-Gauge

description.text:
This is a modified dust shoe from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1892044 . It's modified to fit cnc4newbie's xcarve slider. It uses the same hardware as the original

Here a few more modifications I did:
a) made the brush slots straight. Bending the brushes was giving me too many problems
b) adjusted the dimensions slightly on the top pieces
c) added screw holes on the TOP_back piece to leave room for the drag chain screws
d) sized the dust collector opening for a 3" fitting. I use a 3" to 4" adapter to connect a 4" line
e) changed it from a magnet to a slide in design. I left a slot for 2 magnets in the back, but I didn't bother. I just use pins where the lower bolts used to be, but I left the slot for the nut anyways. Magnets didn't like the weight of a 4" hose anyways.

The sketchup file is attached as well.

print_settings.Notes:: Layer height defaults to .2 mm but is adjustable. Set layer_height and impression_depth as appropriate.

description.text:
Customization Instructions:

  1. Install OpenSCAD
  2. Get the latest version of the dogtag and qr code from https://github.com/X-Illuminati/glyphinator
  3. Find dogtag.scad in the example-projects/dogtag/ directory and open it in OpenSCAD.
  4. Provide customized values for the variables in the "Modify these parameters" section. See the usage notes at the top of the file for hints.
  5. Set mark_space_select=0 before rendering and exporting the STL.
  6. After printing, fill in the holes with a dark epoxy or similar material.

Dualstruders / Multimaterial:
I have no idea if this will actually print in a combined form. May need to scale up feature size to get reasonable performance. I suspect the result will still include a wipe tower that is 3 times the size of the actual model.
Create one model with mark_space_select=0 and a second model with mark_space_select=1 and combine them in your slicer software.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Set mark_space_select=0 before rendering and exporting the STL.
Print in opaque, white filament.

Layer height defaults to .2 mm but is adjustable. Set layer_height and impression_depth as appropriate.

Most quick response code scanners require black marks on a white background.
Other colors besides black can be used as long as they are dark enough to offer sufficient contrast.

A good method is to print out only the base form of the dogtag (mark_space_select=0) in white and then add the black parts afterwards.

  1. Mix up some 5-minute epoxy with a few drops of black ink.
  2. Spread the epoxy over the surface of the quick response code.
  3. Ensure that it is mashed into all of the crevices. Air bubbles are the enemy.
  4. Let cure for 24 hours.
  5. Sand down the surface until the white plastic shows through again. Some parts may not be completely level, so you might have to scrape the epoxy away with a knife.

This is a project I designed just because I wanted to design something in fusion 360, I also wanted to learn a bit about the whole piston assembly in an engine. In order to print this you need to rotate all case pieces, the piston pin, the piston pin lock, and the cylinder 83.9 degrees on the y axes, then you rotate the piston head 270 degrees on the Y. the cam shaft gets turned 90 degrees on the x axes, the support cam shaft gets turned 270 on the x. this should be every thing, I know it seems like a lot but it only takes a couple of seconds I just didn't want people to have to troubleshoot it themselves. I tried to do all this in fusion 360 but I couldn't. This thing is super tiny for some reason in my slicer, if it is tiny for you scale it to 600% and it will be good. I put a lot of work into this project so I figured I would upload it to Thingiverse. it is super cool once it is done and is a good demonstration.

PS. you will need 2 case upper pieces

title: Playseat Challenge steering bar looseness fix.

description.text:
EDIT:

I UPDATED THE DESIGN TO BE A TIGHTER FIT AND EASIER TO INSTALL. THEY'RE SLIGHTLY DIFFERENT FROM THE ONE IN THE INSTALLATION PHOTOS, BUT THE PARTS INSTALL THE SAME WAY AS BEFORE.

These two parts are designed to remove the play in the steering bar of the Challenge racing rig, where it connects to the seat frame.

title: 1,3 GHz helical RHCP/LHCP antenna
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a simple holder for making a helical antenna for frequencies in the 1.3 GHz range
Be sure to check the instructions! Update: The base had an error, fixed Update 2: added both polarisations

Needed supplies:
  • Solid copper wire, with or without mantle (depending on the fit)
  • A matching stub, made according to this tutorial:
    http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1377791
  • Antenna reflector, see above link
  • 50 ohm Coax wire
  • 4x short m3 screw and nut (alternatively, good glue)
    • Print 1 base, print 4 modules per turn.
    Warning: Remove the triangular support from the slot and clean up any residu.
    They should then slide into each other firmly, at 90 degrees of one another, you may or may not want to use glue (with more than 3 turns i'd use glue) Coil the wire around something round and then insert it into the holders, dab of CA and they will stay in place firmly.
    Screw the base to the reflector with m3 screws or glue it. Pictures will follow

description.text:
This is just a concept that I hope to do in wood. I will print this out first to see if everything works.

To take this to wood, you create a hexagonal cylinder the length of the block whose thickness is the same as the pine block. You need to leave material for the axles. Finally, you cut 22.5 degree miters in front of the font axle and behind the rear axle. You then flip the ends up and glue them back on. Then you have to do a lot of contour sanding and glue the lost weight back into the tail.

I am going for something that looks like a banana.

After extensive research to find exact dimensions of the real Apollo Guidance Computer (AGC) Display/Keyboard (DSKY), we created these files in order to publish on Instructables the set of Open Source files and Instructions for anyone to build his own DSKY Replica before the famous 50th Anniversary of Neil Armstrong's first step on the Moon.
https://www.instructables.com/id/Open-Apollo-Guidance-Computer-DSKY/

We then LAUNCHED a Kickstarter (currently in progress with some Early Birds discounts still available) offering various pieces of our Open DSKY Replica. If you 3D print your enclosure yourself, you are already saving money on a kit!
https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/438986934/open-dsky-apollo-50th-anniversary-make-100

Please visit opendsky.com for more info.

We print the Bezel, Top Plate and Mid Ring on Grey material, while the Bottom and Battery Door are printed in Black.

title: Bullet Feeder Parts
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
02/11/18: Added support for 45 caliber drop spring (Bullet Drop Switch Unit and Spring Housing). Probably will work with 10mm but have not tried. Pipe bending springs mouth openings and overall length do very by manufacturer, see picture.

A combination of parts that support the excellent Bullet Feeder Design by AmmoMike83.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2504314

If you think his design is to small or even too big for your needs, download OpenScad and run the script he provides, and have it your way.

Most of the designs here are my own, though the main body design that is just a minor remix to suite my needs.

Be certain you find the note for the part you plan on printing, read that, as I'll note any problems I had with that part.

On a Dillon XL650 with case feeder hopper and dillons' primer feeder, I can load 600 rounds per 65 to 70 minutes. Thats real world with occasional upside down case, misfeed ect (not running it like a madman...). More than 5000 rounds, yes it works.

I've used the Mr. Bullet feeder bullet drop die (9mm), perfect function.

I could not upload my files in folders so this is kind of slammed - Sorry. I had related parts in an individual folder, generally with a text note explaining what I did, you might want to do this. As you would expect, a V3 part was an improvement over V2, etc.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

See Part Specific Note

Infill:

100%, Man Thingi's

Notes:

Usually 0.2mm prints are just fine on small parts, 0.3mm works just fine for large parts at a fast print speed of 120mm/s. Everything is PLA. 0.1mm resolution on the anchor, meant less filing, small parts were generally printed at 60mm/s.

Faster prints speed really heat up the steppers and internals, I went to quiet fans then realized this, and put in better cooling fans and did mods for airflow.

3D Software

Netfabb - was used to add some area on the main body, very minor remix. This application is fairly intuitive for working and modifying solids.

FreeCad - Everything else was done with this software. Not at all intuitive but quite powerful if you can figure out how to trick it into doing what you want. Basically you add or delete shapes together but they are never lost (unless you delete them) and can be re-edited by entering dimensional changes. If you import a solid into this software you have to convince the software that it is a solid, generally making it a mesh then convert to solid; good luck, sometimes it takes and other times, well try again... Useful, basic support is non-existent.

print_settings.Notes:: See summary for what models I printed, and which I didn't, and which I used supports for.

title: Catit Cat Fountain Spouts
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My cat was being picky lately about not drinking out of the cat fountain, and instead wanting the bathroom sink turned on for him all the time... so I made some sink-like attachments for the Catit Cat Fountain.

Models are oriented how I printed them for the ones I actually printed, which are:

Pipe - Full Fins -- Printed WITHOUT supports, post-process heated x-acto knife and cut off 5mm from the top of the fins.

Spout - Paraboloid -- Printed WITH supports touching build plate.

Spout - 90° Chute, 16° Incline, Sliced Small -- Printed WITHOUT supports.

Spout - 180° Pipe, 40mm Vertical, 30mm Arc -- Printed WITH supports touching build plate.

Spout - 180° Pipe, 30mm Vertical, 20mm Arc -- Printed WITH supports touching build plate.

The 180° round pipes have a built-in support inside the peak of the arc to avoid needing anything else.

I did NOT print the others.

The partial fins pipe is a WIP, but likely needs a bevel off the short side of the fins to avoid needing supports, but might work without it. I ended up using my post-processed original full fin pipe.

The box chute likely should get rotated like the others onto the chute edges, and support under the box.

The larger 90 degree angled slice chute should print fine without support since the smaller version did. I would think the non-sliced one would as well.

The 90 degree sliced pipe spout is anyone's guess as to how it would turn out. It was made with two pipes at 90 degree angle to each other, just nudged into place by hand, with cylinder holes to clean it out at the junction, and a quarter sphere back piece nudged into place with a sphere hole then cut out of that. It may not even be water-tight, as it was just an idea between the 180 degree arc spouts, and the box chute, before moving on to the angled chutes, and finally the paraboloid.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini v1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.175

Infill:

20%

Notes:

See summary for what models I printed, and which I didn't, and which I used supports for.

As said in the Summary, I used a heated X-Acto knife to cut off 5mm or so of the top of the full fin pipe fins to allow the spouts to be seated on it before I started designing the partial fin pipe, but ultimately never printed the partial one.

X-Acto knife to take off any stray burrs/unseemly seam marks. A little light sanding with 180 grit sandpaper on some of them.

Full fin pipe modeled after the original Catit Flower attachment base from measurements taken with my Neiko digital calipers, and then designed in TinkerCad. Partial fin version modified from that.

All spouts created entirely in TinkerCad with no other input, from only Basic shapes, with the exception of the 180 degree pipes which also use Glenn Reimche's "Bent Pipe v2" Shape Generator from https://api.tinkercad.com/libraries/1nuPowLvX76/2/docs/index.html

author: Dolly1

description.text:
Minimal extruder housing for use with the Printrbot Gearhead drive gears, 1.75mm filament, and a NEMA17 motor.

The secondary gear is inserted from the side, and the additional M3 screws or setscrews hold the gear in place and adjust the tension. It's designed to use a bowden coupler from RobotDigg. Filament is Emerald Green PETG from Atomic Filament.

I prefer to use 48mm NEMA17 motors with the Gearhead drive gears, but a 40mm version can be used to reduce weight or a larger one if more torque is needed. Make sure the setscrew doesn't stick out on the primary drive gear, especially if using a motor without a D-shaft.

There is also a NEMA14 version and info about several other dual drive bowden extruders I've just uploaded on thrinter.com

This Bison latifrons skeleton, created by the Idaho Virtual Laboratory of the Idaho Museum of Natural History, was created digitally by combining scanned fossil specimens from Bureau of Reclamation collections. Because it's creation is not unlike the famous Mary Shelley character, this model has been fondly named "Frankenbison." For more information, please visit http://virtual.imnh.isu.edu/BoR.

author: jkkhuang

title: Printrbot Model 3 X/Y Axis cable chain support

description.text:
Note: After several hours of printing with the Model 3, I'm not completely convinced this will be a complete solution to the issue. I've seen the cable sag slightly, and while it hasn't jammed yet I wouldn't put it past it to slide down. I'll leave this part up, but might try to design something that will attach to the bracket on the extruder.

The printrbot Model 3 has a horizontal cable chain for the X/Y axis - while it is affixed with two screws on either end (two at the extruder, two at the frame), I don't trust that it will stay horizontal over time. Since this is a large-format printer, a failure with the cable chain binding could destroy a large print.

I designed a tiny block that fits underneath the spool holder bracket. This gives the cable chain a bit of support and (hopefully!) creates a fulcrum keeping it horizontal.

You will need to print both parts - one goes under the left bracket, the other the right. I printed mine with enough bottom layers to have a completely solid part between the bracket and base.
