title: Filament feed thru for LACK table top mounted dry box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
*** Spotted an issue with two parts that will prevent proper printing. If you have downloaded this before Feb. 1 2018, delete that and download again.

I noticed lots of folks using the IKEA SAMLA plastic totes as dry box setups for filament storage and such. I saw lots of creations that had filament rolls hung inside the box, and filament fed out the side/s of the box through various ports or openings to get to the printer.Some are quite creative and at one point I was going to combine elements from 2 different Things for my own printer station.

Then, I bought the LACK tables, printed the parts to stack those, then noted that I was having a lifting/curling issue again and needed to partially or completely enclose the printer to prevent that (I noted it prints much better if the room it's in is a bit warmer than normal, so an enclosure seemed a good idea). I decided I was going to put the dry box on top of those tables (after securing them to the wall in an unused walk-in closet in our house), and then I noted I would have to make additional cuts in the plexiglass sides to allow the filament to get in, and that most likely I'd not be able to put the tables and printer in the corner where I wanted to because of that, and my wife would complain if I had it in the middle of the wall instead of the corner where I said I was going to put it, etc. etc.

Then it occurred to me that I could feed the filament down and out the bottom center of the dry box. I started looking for Things to do that, and didn't really see any. I found filament guides made to go in the top of and thru the LACK table, but nothing for a dry box.

So some hours of design (and a few hours of test prints) later, I give you this Thing! I have a flanged tube to go through the table top (use screws or bolts, or not, your choice). It is indented to receive another rounded flange mounted on the outside bottom of the dry box, that rounded bit sits inside (should be close to snug I think) that table flange. This does two things: Helps you to easily line up the box again should you move it for some reason, and due to weight (obey gravity, it's the law!) that same piece helps to hold it in place should you get excessive vibrations or something or other (or toddlers that like to poke at things). Then there is an inside flange for the inside of the dry box, wider than the others at the base for some support, with a tube and rounded funnel setup to take the filament. That funnel and the table top tube both have a decent sized cavity in them able to hold a chunk of synthetic sponge or something to both dust/clean the filament as it goes through, and act as a vapor/moisture barrier for the dry box. It is a large opening in both cases, so a large piece of sponge could be used. I'd thought that with folks doing ABS filament and the like, some kind of a barrier against fumes (or sucking in too much cold air for the ventilated enclosures) would be a good idea.

Using this Thing to hold my spools: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1511834. My plastic totes are wide enough that I can get 8 mounted rolls of filament on two rods (4 on the left, 4 on the right) and two more rolls laying on the bottom of the box (storage).

It's designed to print as is with minimal infill and no supports as I dislike using them if I don't really have to.

Again, I did not design this with the Ikea plastic tote in mind as I don't own one. Similar totes were available at my local hardware store for a slightly better price so I bought those instead. From what I can see, they are very similar in the bottom box dimensions to the Ikea one so this should work for those too (Ikea box appears to have a millimeter or two more bottom clearance than mine does).

I would suggest that if you are going to setup as I did, you add a couple strips of wood or tubing or something on to the table top to help keep the dry box in place (keeps it from sliding around, just in case, safety first and all that). Also keep in mind that my plastic tote box is a bit wider and longer than the Ikea version. If I run a spool rod down the middle, I can get 6 spools on it with some clearance between each one. If I put in two rods running front to back (width) instead of one rod side to side (length), I can get 8 rolls like I said with space beneath those for two more spools. The funnel on the inside box flange on this is setup to that height (give or take) for my box. I added the rounded edges and stuff on the funnel just in case it ended up tall for some other box setup (filament likes running over and around rounded edges). That's the kind of setup I made this Thing for.

Of course, you could forgo the funnel part entirely and just print two copies of the box bottom flange (one on the inside, the other on the outside) and feed it that way if you like, but I was in a design mood and wanted to do something weird and different and definitely unique. And it just now occurs to me that if I found and modified or created my own spool holder designed to hold a spool on it's side instead of standing up, I could have 10 available spools of filament in my dry box, I just have to open it and feed through whichever color or type of filament I want to use. Yeah I know, I shouldn't open it unless I have to. So far today I've had it open a dozen times and the humidity level went from 26% to 28%, and is already back to 27% 30 minutes since I last opened it, so I'm not too worried about opening the dry box.

Anyway for those that don't know, the whole point of using a dry box is to keep your filament dry a.k.a. not full of moisture from humid air. You keep the spools in there until you need them, then take out the one your going to use, use it for however long the print takes, then PUT IT BACK IN THE BOX (people forget to do that). Buy either a renewable/reusable air dryer or dehydrator (Eva Dry comes to mind), or get a bunch of the little desiccant packs that your filament is packed with and toss them all in an airtight (or as air tight as you can get it) container. The Ikea SAMLA plastic totes seem to work well, but I found similar containers at the local hardware store for less (and no waiting for delivery) so I used those instead. I have a cheap little digital thermostat that also reads humidity so I threw that in the box as well just to monitor things. My box is regularly at 26% humidity, which is actually quite dry really (most homes are between 35% and 45% humidity). Seems to work well, and the Eva Dry are reusable by plugging them into an electrical outlet for half a day so they can heat up and dry out again, then reuse them a couple hundred times I think.

PLA, PETG, Nylon, ABS... doesn't matter what filament you use, it should be in a dry box. If the humidity doesn't bother the filament, the box will help keep dust and other debris out of your filament along with bugs, pets, perhaps small children and such.

I've got some pictures up. That last image, I have the inside and bottom flanges mounted on the base of the box, drilled my holes and used M3 screws, washers and nuts since that is what I had on-hand. I have the box propped up on a couple empty filament spools and I set the table top flange underneath so you can see how its supposed to work.

UPDATE 2/3/18:
Added two different feed adapters, both setup to take the same kind of tube fittings you'd use in a Bowden extrusion setup. I know lots of folks like to use these tubes on their dry box, so I thought I should add something to account for those. Both single and double filament adapters are included. Simply glue this to the table top flange in whatever orientation you need (doesn't matter for the single), or drill and screw if you like. This is for people that already have a dry box they like, and just need something to get the filament fed in to a LACK enclosure. I also added some filament guides to inside the dry box with the intent of guiding the filament from the the two end spools (referring to my dry box setup) towards the funnel. I tried feeding from one without these, and inadvertently got filament wound around (and kind of in) the spool next to that one. The guides allow the filament to feed straight off the spool, then make a 90 degree turn towards the funnel. I've got two versions of each, some are straight/level, the others have a slight tilt in them to help direct the filament (should someone ever need something like that).

UPDATE 2/21/2018:
Added a shorter version of the inside box flange with better supports. Not that it really needs better supports, but I broke one on mine when I bumped a full filament spool into it, so....

UPDATE 3/10/2018:
Added an updated version of the table top flange due to issues some people were seeing using different slicers on the object.

Printer:

ANET A8

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Adjust infill and resolution to your liking. It shouldn't need any supports, and raft use is always at user discretion.

Any photo/s I put up are will be of the parts in .24 resolution at 10% infill. Except for the table flange and nut, those had to be printed in .2 resolution or the threads on the nut wouldn't come out right for me.

Clean it if you like, or not, using your preferred method for the material you printed it with. Me, I print all my machine parts in PLA, and I print them at a rougher quality (.24 or .28) because I don't need them to be smooth and pretty. I need them to be done now and just work.

I used 3D Builder (free with Windows 10) to make the whole thing, and the online NetFabb site to check/repair some models after they were extensively edited (or mutilated) again by me.

The outer diameter of the table top feed tube is 26.5mm, so when drilling through the table, I'd suggest using either a 27mm spade bit or hole saw, or a 1 & 1/16 Inch spade bit or hole saw in the US. The table top is 50mm thick, and the tube is about 52mm long overall, so it should just barely protrude past the underside of the table when inserted and teh nut for it is tightened down. The threads on the end of it should extend another 1cm or so, and the nut goes on it to lock it in place and seal up around where the table was drilled. If you decide to screw the table flange down, keep in mind that the LACK tables are low priced for a reason, and the material itself is very thin and backed by cardboard. Also, ROTATE the tube 45degrees so that the screws or bolts or whatever you use on this flange (I suggest flush or recessed screws) don't interfere with the bolts/screws on the bottom of your dry box bottom/underside flange (also using flush bolts or machine screws there). Since the screw holes aren't countersunk yet, the screws/bolts could interfere with each other if you line all the holes up together.

When you go to drill the table for the feed tube, I would suggest using a smaller drill bit first to get a starter hole going (drill all the way through, probably from the bottom since you want that hole directly above where the filament would enter your printer or the filament guide for your printer). Then using the larger drill bit, drill the bottom until you hit the cardboard, then do the same with the top all the while using that smaller hole as a guide for the larger bit. Then dig out the cardboard with a pliers or Sheetrock knife or razor or switchblade or whatever you like (I just ran the spade bit and let that chew it up and cleaned up the mess after). Just don't go crazy with the paper stuff as that is basically the infill for this table. Rip it out without care and you could have problems down the road.

One other tip: Always check and measure and eyeball everything before you drill or cut a thing. When you've looked at and measured it all, then do it again and look for the the thing you missed. Then start cutting, drilling, what have you. The top of the LACK table is 550mm squared, so measure in 275mm from a side and the front and you've found the center. My machine is actually a bit back from center, and I drilled to have the filament come in right above my printer instead.

That very last photo... I have 10 spools of filament in there. There is enough space to add some side-spool holders, so now I must find or create some.

author: buzzwang

description.text: Made this for my Retro Arcade bartop machine Punisher theme

Wanted to get some practice in OpenSCAD design with interest in geometry and pattern generation. What better way than to design some cool coasters?

This visually pleasing diamond design is based on the number Phi, "the golden ratio," and can be edited in the OpenSCAD file included. There are only two variables to change, the size of the diamonds, and the width of the lines. The coaster itself is 10cm in diameter, which should be large enough for almost any cup you can throw on it.

I've included .stl for 5mm size diamonds with 2mm width lines. If you'd like any other sizes uploaded in .stl form let me know, but the OpenSCAD file can help you there. Just edit 2 vars, render, export, slice, print, and enjoy!

I plan to make a few more geometric 'designs' for this same type coaster 'base' as well as a coaster holder for them soon, too.

author: k7zpj

print_settings.Notes:: This is my first customizer project.

title: Drum for Rock or Media Tumbler

description.text:
This is a customizable drum with built in agitators for a media tumbler (rock tumbler). I made this for my Affordable Rock Tumbler Build, but I wanted it to be customizable so I can adjust the size without changing all the variables and sizes for every little piece. I guess they call it parametric? I don't know. I call it simple.

The DrumSize vector is the height (DrumSize[0]) and the width radius (DrumSize[1]) of the drum. So if you want your drum to be 100mmx100mm then you need to set the vector to [100,50] because radius is half the width of the circle. WallThick is of course the wall thickness. How thick do you need the walls of your drum to be. finCnt is the number of agitator fins inside the drum. You want more, less doesn't matter. The script will dynamically adjust the spacing and size of the agitators. The agitator fins are 5% the width of the drum wide and 10% the width of the drum long (how far they protrude). The lid is fixed to have a lip that is 10% the height of the drum. This gives plenty of coverage in my tests so far to keep a good solid connection while tumbling around for days on end. $fn is the number of fragments a circle is broken into. This effects how smooth the curves and angles will be. It's an OpenSCAD built in variable, but I include it because some people like to adjust this variable. I've found 60 to be pretty clean, but keep in mind that the more fragments you break it into the larger the resulting files and gcode will be and the longer it will take Customizer to render it. Anyhow, if Customizer is working (as of this writing it's not) play with it and have some fun.

EDIT: Added a lidTol variable for lid tolerance. A positive value here will increase the inner diameter of the lid. You can use this to account for how snug or loose the fit of the lid is to the drum.

Printer:

Custom Build Cartesian

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

None

Notes:

I printed this at 0.3 to make it as sturdy as possible. I printed the drum in PETG and the lid in flex. If you print the lid in something else it will probably need to be widened. I like flex because it stretches over the drum for a tight seal.

This is my first customizer project.

print_settings.Notes:: Da Vinci Jr 2.0 Mix

description.text:
See video at https://youtu.be/Bti2-rvxHR0

Braq, the articulated poseable dragon, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:854575, is one of the most wonderful things on this site. When I saw it, I knew I had to make it! But as I looked at it more, I realized that with very slight modifications it would make a wonderful puppet. At first I planned to add a lot of loops to the various parts, but as I worked with it I realized that just drilling small holes with a Dremel tool did the job most of the time.
Here are the instructions for the puppet:
1) The HEAD does work better with a loop. The slightly modified file is given here.
2) Otherwise print all the parts for Braq normally.
3) Follow the instructions for assembly, BUT instead of elastic, use nylon thread (or fishing line) and don't pull it entirely tight. Just a little slack is all you need.
3A) I shortened the TAIL by about 5 joints to make it easier to manipulate.
4) I found that gluing the three BODY parts together worked better to keep them straight. I also found that gluing the FEET to the lower legs kept them pointing forward.
5) I added an extra joint to join the upper and middle WINGS on their trailing edge.
This left me with a floppy mess of a dragon! Now it was time to make him fly.
I printed the four parts of the controller, and the two loops. There are extra holes in the controller to allow the legs to be hooked up but that makes a very complicated puppet. You can try it.
Glue the controller together. You can adjust it slightly to fit your hand.
String the head, and drill holes in the two body parts and string them. These 3 strings determine the length of all the other strings so be careful with them.
I attached two strings to the tail and tied them into a triangle on a single string. The tail was the hardest part to make move realistically for me.
Now for the wings! We want him to fly realistically. I found that making a"pyramid" of three things attached to the upper wing kept it level and gave a good flapping action. Note how the wings connect to the controller and loop so one pull controls them both.
Willie-O, our cat, loves the puppet!

Requires 2 M6 x 1 bolts, about 30-45 mm in length. Supposed to support seatposts from 22.0 - 31.6 mm in diameter.

I think the binding post bolt is an M5 x 0.8, & the post is 35 mm long.

I don't recommend this for 3D printing, but for machining.

title: Power supply cover for Flying Bear P905

description.text:
This is a power supply cover for Flying Bear P905 with USB port of Raspberry PI, three XT60 connectors, and power cord plug.

The three XT60 connectors are make of 2 battery clamp XT60 holder (in the center) and a re-mix to include two side mount with the power supply cover. It requires two M3 screws with nut to clamp them all together. To mount this to the power supply cover, you will need two plastic 3mm screws.

The USB plug is designed to hold an iPhone 2A plug. To mount this to the power supply cover, you will need two plastic 3mm screws.

The power supply cover is re-mix and extended a few millimeters. Please note that the outlet plug don't have hole. You need to drill two holes. In addition, if you want to control a SSR relay, consider drive another hole about 3/8 inch in one of the corner.

In order to fit to the printer frame, you need to drill new hole as it is a bit long with the power supply cover. Drill the new mount hole on the frame as far out as possible. After you drill the right side (the side with plug), place the power supply over it, mark the second hole, and drill the second hole.

Flying Bear P905

description.text:
My first Thing!

This is a simple insertable end-cap for a metal pipe used as a closet rod for hang-up clothes. The file is scaled for a 7/8 inch inner diameter, so it will most likely need to be scaled. The scaling process is pretty simple if you use the following equation:

x*(7/8 inch) = (desired inner diameter as a fraction), solve for "x"

For example, if your pipe has an inner diameter of 1 5/32 inch, then the equation would be:

x (7/8) = (37/32)
x = (8 37)/(7 * 32)
x ~= 1.321

So, 1.32ish would be your scaling factor in your printer software. Enjoy! :-)

Printrbot

Printer:

Yes

Notes:

The flat shell of the round cap prints a little thin, but doesn't seem to affect the performance of the end cap in its end-cappy duties.

The supports will need to be cleaned away, so I advise printing in an orientation that places them wherever you find easiest to deal with. I turned the file with the round head downward so the inner contact surfaces would be clean and smooth.

Story Time!

My mother-in-law needed new end-0caps for her closet rod, and asked if I'd whip up a pair for her. I, naturally, said "Printrbot Fabrication Team, away!" Or something like that.

title: Futuristic Flying Station Wagon "WagenCorps Revamp AD" prototype "Revamp-X"

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/cJnkTbid8ds

Warning: The following may be a bit confusing.

This car and its manufacturer are completely figments of my imagination. The manufacturer is called "WagenCorps" and is a joint project between Volvo, Subaru and Cadillac (none of which I own) devoted to the resurrection of the Station Wagon, which had gone extinct by the figment-of-my-imagination future which the car comes from. In this future, the auto industry is mainly devoted to the manufacture of flying cars known as "Air-Drivers", abbreviated to AD in model names. All of my futuristic car models come from this future. Annotated image of marque symbol is enclosed.

This model is of WagenCorps's first experimental car, model-named "Revamp AD" and dubbed "Revamp-X" by the project directors. The body design is based on Volvo's 1980 265 station wagon model.

title: Flower Pot inserts for Concrete Planter

description.text: I printed the flower pot Mold_1 by AndresQuijas and poured concrete to complete. It turned out perfectly. Afterwards, I realized that my Mom would want the option to easily remove and swap out different herbs or plants, and have a drainage option that didn't spill water everywhere when she watered her plants. So I designed this. These both have small feet and drainage holes. The original Mold_1 was scaled to 80% when I printed it, so my design is scaled to fit inside of the completed flower pot . Pretty sure it will scale up or down accordingly. Just note your scale before printing these inserts. enjoy!

title: Futuristic Flying Station Wagon "WagenCorps Velie AD"

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/0N5NxyRQNfu

Warning: The following may be a bit confusing.

This car and its manufacturer are completely figments of my imagination. The manufacturer is called "WagenCorps" and is a joint project between Volvo, Subaru and Cadillac (none of which I own) devoted to the resurrection of the Station Wagon, which had gone extinct by the figment-of-my-imagination future which the car comes from. In this future, the auto industry is mainly devoted to the manufacture of flying cars known as "Air-Drivers", abbreviated to AD in model names. All of my futuristic car models come from this future. Annotated image of marque symbol is enclosed.

        This model is named "Velie" in the tradition of naming car models after old, obscure or otherwise-discontinued automakers in the futuristic facet from which this whole futuristic-car business stems. The Velie (pronounced vee-lee) model here is named after a make originally connected to the John Deere farm equipment company that began making cars in 1902 and ended car production in the 1920s.

         For practicality's sake, the real model would have a folding set of stairs built into the top of the root of each wing, a feature carried from Cadillac's Musket AD minivan.

Quick edit of the diamonds coaster design ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2772489 ) with circles instead of diamonds.

This visually pleasing circles design is based on the number Phi, "the golden ratio," and can be edited in the OpenSCAD file included. There are only two variables to change, the size of the circles, and the width of the lines. The coaster itself is 10cm in diameter, which should be large enough for almost any cup you can throw on it.

I've included .stl for 10mm size circles with 2mm width lines. If you'd like any other sizes uploaded in .stl form let me know, but the OpenSCAD file can help you there. Just edit 2 vars, render, export, slice, print, and enjoy!

I plan to make a few more geometric 'designs' for this same type coaster 'base' as well as a coaster holder for them soon, too.

title: Keychain Separator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you want to remove items like USB flash drives, key fobs, or other key chain-bound tools without fumbling with key rings, print my key chain separator. These devices are typically made of metal, cost around seven US dollars on Amazon, and separate with the push of a button, like this example. My version of the key chain separator is designed to be fully 3D printable without support. Rather than a button push, the pieces of this device separate with a twist and a pull--motion that is uncommon even in stuffed pockets. A simple locking mechanism means that it should only break apart when you want it to. If you need more key rings, consider printing this thing.

Update on 2-9-18

I have fixed the part clearance to provide some extra room for inconsistencies of printing and discrepancies between printers. The result is a slightly looser fit, but less required post-printing and hopefully more accessibility no matter the tolerances a user's printer is capable of.

Update on 2-18-18

I further improved the fit of the two parts. Be sure to set your print resolution to 0.15 mm.

Enjoy!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

10%

Notes:

The pieces should be oriented as they appear in the previews when printing. I designed the separator around these settings, so it is imperative that you use them. Printing at a lower resolution, for example, not only makes the icons on the parts look bad but introduces fit-ruining friction. I have only tested this device with PLA plastic. Use the following instructions also:

  • Use a skirt ten lines wide and connected to the parts to improve build plate adhesion. If you do not know what this means, refer to the third image in the gallery.
  • Use the same brand of filament for each part. Different brands of filament contract to different degrees as they cool. If one contracts more than the other, the parts' fit will be ruined.
The two pieces of the separator may not connect and disconnect smoothly. To fix this and break in the separator, twist the pieces on and off twenty times.

Here are some useful printing tips in order to print it successfully.

1) Print this with the game card holder slots facing up so it prints this without supports inside the card holder slots. Printing otherwise will still work, but requires more time and work, as well as patience.

title: Pinball drop targets WITH RESET DIY

description.text:
A modular pinball drop target.
As part of my DIY pinball project i needed to design some drop targets.
This is a complete/final model that works just fine.

I used a small piece of elastic band to put tension on the target, i tried using a spring but it was too much for the servo. perhaps a softer spring could work.

Servo motor: Tower pro (13mm*24mm)
Micro switch with NC & NO contacts.

The model was designed in Fusion360 and is included for download. It has been a long work in progress and some mistakes were made along the way.
As for the reset mechanism, well this was just the best of the bad ideas i had and it seems to work fine in testing so long as the servo's had plenty of current yo work with.

It is modular with a common bolt hole in the base so you can connect as many as you like.

See it in action over on youtube https://youtu.be/ypVkQ8xWw9M

Enjoy :)

description.text:
I recently purchased a 3D scanner for creating STL files of scanned objects.
It is from Eora 3D, and has a calibration target made of 5.75mm acrylic with a dot pattern
printed on it for calibration of the scanner.

It is important to have the target secured upright when doing the calibration, but there is no good way to do this without something to hold the target vertically.

I designed a simple stand to fulfill this purpose. It covers 6mm by 60mm of the center bottom
of the target, but it is away from the dot pattern, and I have successfully calibrated the scanner with this stand in place.

The slot in the stand is 6mm, should be plenty of tolerance for your 3D printer to not make the fit too tight. Mine fit just right.

Print with the triangular end on the bed, slot oriented vertically.

title: Dual mosfet  for Flying Bear P905

description.text:
Dual Mosfet mount for Flying Bear P905 This is a remix of the Anet A8 dual mosfet mount. It is mounted as the fitting washer in the top two screws. In addition, I include another re-mix of the fan cover to replace the 40mm fan with an 80mm fan. It is much quieter. (I can't seem to find the original fan cover link.)

Update 2/22/2018: Add version 2 to support fan cooling

When I start printing using ABS with heater bed at 90 degree, the mosfet really got hot. Therefore, I now have version 2 which includes fan to cool the bed mosfet. Here is the list of change with version 2:

  1. Lower the mount point to 3mm
  2. Add mounting bracket and 40mm fan mount

You can use 3mm screw with nut to mount the bracket to the mosfet mounting plate. For the 40mm fan, use #6 self driving screw with 1/2" length or something close to this. The 40mm fan mount is based on https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2354999.

author: locnhinho

description.text:
This took a few tries to get to good working order, and it has a few kinks left, but it works pretty well!
After reading some research papers covering anemometer cup shape and theory, I decided to try testing one of the more rare 'wing' type shapes. It's far more effective than my last version that used the round cups.
This version also has mounts for a second level of cups, although I haven't yet put those on my machine yet, it should smooth things out even more.
The vane included fits, but I ended up cutting mine up and put a bearing from a fidget spinner on the post - it's very sensitive.

This anemometer is huge, with a 5 foot circumference. This means that the wheel goes slowly enough for easy counting by elementary and junior high students.

I've included a chart that will help translate spins per minute into miles per hour.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kIC8YpRmX68

title: Filament holder with  bearing for Flying Bear P905

description.text:
Filament roller holder with pitch bearing 9x17x4mm. With this, almost no friction as compare to the original metal hanger. You need to print two inner and two outer mounts.

Require these additional hardware:

  1. One 1/8" threaded rod (need to cut to proper length)
  2. Two 1/8 nuts

To assemble:

  1. Measure the current length and cut the 1/8" threaded rod accordingly.
  2. Slide two bearing into the inner mount. One on each end.
  3. Slide the outer mount into the inner mount with bearing in between.
  4. Repeat for the other set.
  5. Slide the 1/8 threaded rod through both. Make sure the larger end position at the opposite end.
  6. Thread the nut on one end.
  7. Wrap the outer mount with some blue painter tape. Otherwise, the filament roll don't grip the mount.
  8. Mount it to the printer frame.

Note: I moved the mount position down quite a bit from the original mount position. You have to drill a new hole. This will allow you to add an out of filament sensor switch. For this, just go to ebay and buy an end stop filament sensor type (see picture). To mount the filament sensor, just zip tie the wire to the printer frame and let it hangs loosely. Otherwise, too much friction.

Update:

After install a new roll of filament, the filament seems to wrap around the spooler. Therefore, I had moved the mounting position back to the original location.

author: ihillway

print_settings.Notes:: The overall form factor lends itself well to 3D printing without support.  I stuck a brim on the bottom to keep it stuck on the bed. I also designed some integral support for overhangs at the mounting face.  Lastly, there are removable support vanes inside the bolt slots and under a curved overhang.

description.text:
My father-in-law is a very talented artist and maker, building elaborate stage sets for his local community and school theaters, among other projects. He has a lovely, enviable workspace a few steps outside his door, stocked with a full wood shop.

He recently contacted me and asked if I could reproduce the Dust Extractor nozzle for his beloved DeWalt DW708. The part is somewhat fragile, and having been knocked a few times, repaired a few times, he discovered, to his irritation, that DeWalt had discontinued the part, classifying it as "obsolete". There is no replacement option.

He lives a ways away, and I couldn't 'pop round' to examine the saw, so we used the mail to send the parts back and forth. I made detailed measurements of the original and then replicated the general shape in Tinkercad.

Tinkercad is NOT the best tool for industrial design, but I am very familiar with its capabilities (and the price is right). I increased the dimensions of the mounting flange, requiring mounting bolts that are 5 mm longer than the original. Not realizing that the overall length is a critical dimension, my first iteration was too long to fit without binding. After some feedback on how version 1 fit, I also made some subtle changes to the the mounting face.

Version 2 reportedly mates to the saw "better than the original"

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20 mm layer height

Infill:

50% for strength

Notes:

The overall form factor lends itself well to 3D printing without support. I stuck a brim on the bottom to keep it stuck on the bed. I also designed some integral support for overhangs at the mounting face. Lastly, there are removable support vanes inside the bolt slots and under a curved overhang.

The part needs a little clean-up before use.
Remove the brim: Snap it off with a pliers and file smooth as desired.
Pluck the supports from inside the bolt slots and the elbow tab notches, trim remnants with Xacto blade
Other supports: There are three vanes that support a convex overhang where one of the mounting bolts must go. A deft swipe with an Xacto blade removes these easily enough.

Good enough is good enough, but I lavished a bit of obsessive trim work on the clean-up, just to make it look nice.

As mentioned, I used Tinkercad to design this. I made a detailed sketch of the pat and then measured critical dimensions with a digital caliper. I took liberty with the dimensions of the mounting tabs and the length of the part. The mounting tab was a win, but the greater length caused clearance issues for the first iteration.

There are a lot of "union" and "difference" operations in building out this part. I find that constructing subassemblies, saving them as discreet STLs and then putting them all together at the end avoids a lot of manifold error problems. Finally, I used Microsoft's Netfabb STL repair tool, and converted the fixed file from 3mf format back to STL's in MeshLab.

The part printed in about 3 hours.

title: Realacc XS220E top plate with VTX and Camera Mounts

description.text:
Realacc XS220E top plate with VTX, Runcam Micro Camera Mounts, 45 degree antenna tube holes and separate FrSky FrSky X4RSB receiver mount, utilizing standoffs. This makes the race quad very organized with all components in their respective places.

This is the second version of this top plate. Did not like mounting camera on the bottom of the plate on the previous version because of props in view, so I designed one with top mounted camera, protected with camera guards.

Top plate includes window for channel display on VTX and pinhole for channel selection button. The plastic canopy which came with this frame looked flimsy and did not have adequate place to house all electronics.

Camera guards can use a 26mm standoff, on top of the camera for hard impacts. Not sure if you can buy this size, I used Dremel tool to cut one to custom size.

Other than that my previous version was printed out of ABS and flown frequently. Plastic did not even get warm from 600mw VTX operation. (and those things normally get really hot)

Anyway enough rambling... have fun printing and flying.

Like and comment if you find this design useful.

title: j-head/e3d v6 mount with mini differential ir sensor for Flying Bear P905

description.text:
J-head/e3d v6 mount plate with mini differential IR sensor for Flying Bear P905

Update 2/17/2018: Add a compact version of the mini ir sensor mount.

e3d v6/j-head mount:

This is the mount plate for e3d/j-head v6 hotend. This is a re-mix of e3d v6 mount plate by TH3D. The STL model is modified to similar size as the u-shape mount - https://reprapchampion.com/products/aluminum-groove-mount-for-e3d-v6-hotend-for-delta-reprap-kossel-mini-3d-printer. This does works and I had printed a few models.

After I made this STL model, I had since moved to an all aluminium mount plate by modify the u-shape mount plate as following:

  1. Drill two holes and threaded them accordingly. The hole offset should be 6.1mm from one of the other set of hole. You don't have to threaded them but will make installing the hotend much simple. (My brother-in-law did this for me since he works in CNC.)
  2. Using the STL mount as model, cut the aluminium to fit the Flying Bear P905 extruder mount bracket. It is so tight in term of space. You can screw both the STL model and the aluminium u-shape plate together. Then hand hex saw off the portion with the opening.
  3. In order to mount this, you need to clip off a bit of the top fin. To do this, assemble the e3d/j-head hotend and position according. For the side that touch the mount bracket, use a cutting plier and clip off a bit.
  4. To mount, first hand tight both screws and make sure it is flat. Then slowly tighten each side - just a little bit each side in rotation.

Included a test model print from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1363023.

Mini IR differential sensor

This mini IR differential sensor is from https://miscsolutions.wordpress.com/mini-height-sensor-board. In order to get this to work with the Flying Bear P905 Marlin FW, you need to modify the firmware to default to digital output and output low on trigger. I had modified the firmware to always default to digital output. Then change the code to drive the LED PIN on trigger and the output pin to low on trigger. Due to this, the wire connection has changed. The file MiniIRSensorSmd.hex is the new firmware with the above changes.

To program the updated firmware, you will need to install those 6 PIN's on the IR sensor. Then use Arduino as an ISP to program the firmware. Many web page provides instruction on how to do this. For wiring, instead using the output in the original 3 PIN connector, use the PIN SCK pin. 

     *                 *                *
   Vcc              MOSI         GND
     *                 *                *
   MISO           SCK           Reset
                 Use this SCK pin instead

This SCK pin will be 5V on non-trigger and 0V on triggered.

For the mount, you now have two options:

Option A: Use the modified DC42 Shield STL model accordingly. It is mounted along with the fan duct.

Option B: Use the ET-compact-mini-ir-sensor-mount.stl. This is a compact version that can be mount on the printer x-axis bracket. In order to do this, you need to solder wire directly on the mini ir sensor board instead using the pin header. The pin header is just to large. With direct soldered wire, it is much more compact. Print setting: 0.2 layer height, 50% infill, print on its side, and add zig-zag support at 5%.

With option B, you can now switch out the 30mm fan with a 40 mm fan. Using the noctua 40mm fan, it is dead quite and absolutely no vibration. In order to mount the 40 mm fan, you need to print yourself a 40mm fan mount from here - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:929326. Please note that I have to scale the x dimension by 102%. Otherwise, it breaks. In addition, when mounting, it does push the fan duct against the x-axis bracket a bit. Just be aware of this. Some day or some one can design a 40 mm fan duct that offsets by 3.8mm.

Notes:

To save printing material, and trouble removing support material, I recommend printing this part upside down. If you print the model as-is, it will use a significant amount of support material and may foul up the shaft hole, requiring drilling to remove.

ABS plastic is recommended due to heat and UV concerns.

I do not recommend going under 50% infill as it will weaken connection points between the shaft and the body, and may result in the knob breaking loose during use.

description.text:
arduino v 1.8.5 , marlin_anet-a8 and am8_mks_base_1.5. ( extruder stock )

_Software Modification :

1 - Connect your printer with your computer via USB cable
2 - open the file you downloaded
3 - Select Arduino Mega 2560 Board ( in the marlin arduino )
4 - In the file you downloaded, File Open > Marlin.ino
5 - Compile and uploaded
6 - Power cycle the entire unit
7 - Calibrate your machine

After Modifications are Completed, perform the steps below
Check/Adjust your stepper driver current to 0.41 volts. You may obtain more information :

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kkjwOxDSCiQ&t=219s

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GXZzqhBer2I&list=PLlcMt_sdtxsCU2y7PDkHt5sT9gSh4AhHK&t=105s&index=120

I designed a Spool Holder for Printrbot sample spools!

This spool is custom designed to hold filament sample spools from Printrbot. I myself have ordered many sample packets from Printrbot in order to have a variety of colors to try printing with and thought that they would probably feed and sit much happier on my Printrbot Simple Metal if they had their own spool! Low and behold, i give you said spool!

Please enjoy and share with fellow Printrbot owners! The spool fits the smal sample rolls of filament that Printrbot provides on their website as single samples and their sample packs! Works very well.

The Spool itself is made up of three parts. 2 sides and a center piece. Print out the 3 parts and will need 8 screws to attach them together. Holes already made in the parts to allow for threaded screws to be used.

Enjoy and happy printing :-) !!

description.text: Gopro mount for the proof uav 5inch miniquad frame

This thing is for using 40mm diameter tools with a Festool cleaner.
The Festool side is for connecting the hose coming from the Festool vacuum, the 40mm side is for connecting a 40mm (ext) hose or a 40mm tool.

On the Festool side there is a shouldering for limiting dust blocking.
On the 40mm side there is a slope for keeping a good flow.

Source file (Dassault Catia V5-6R2012) is provided, hope someone will remix it.

I printed it on a Formlabs Form2 with FLGPGR03 resin (5 h 5 min / 100 µm /47.0 mL). It gave a very good result.

remixed_from.author: Petclaud
remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 MK3 Raspberry Pi Camera Bed Mount

title: Prusa i3 MK3 Raspberry Pi Camera Bed Mount - Updated

description.text:
I remixed my own thing (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2756864) for two reasons:

  • With the previous design the bed mount and the "pole" to attach the camera to were one piece which it is not the strongest solution
  • I have now added Partykongenbaddi's air intake funnel to my printers (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2718992) and hence I needed a longer version since the funnel was crashing into the camera

Hence I now designed a camera mount which consists of 4 parts: the camera mount, a separate 'pole', a camera enclosure front and back.

The camera mount snaps onto the bed Y-carriage of the MK3 - it has a slot that fits perfectly around the carriage. You only need one zip-tie to avoid the piece sliding off the Y-carriage and in order to fix it even more tight. Another slot is provided for the ribbon cable of the camera. If you want you can use some extra zip-ties to guide the ribbon cable a bit towards the printer. To mount the 'pole', just use a square M3 nut and a M3 bolt/screw to install the 'pole' onto the bed mount. The camera enclosure has 3mm holes in the lips to fix it to the 'pole' with an M3 screw/nut. You can use the spare M3 bolts/screws and nuts as provided with your printer.

I have made 45 degree angled versions and a straight versions as well as left and right versions. The angled versions make sure the camera mount is parallel to the bed.If you use the intake duct as described above, you will need the 'long' versions - if not, you can use the shorter versions.

The Pi camera I use is a wide angle (fish eye) version.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You will have to print the bed mount with supports (it will be minimal supports, just for the slot snapping to the Y-carriage), the rest of the components not. I printed these in PLA since and this is strong enough.

Encontré un diseño de cllip para sujetar un cristal de 30x30 a la cama de la tornado: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2722668
Compré un paquete de 4 espejos LOTS en Ikea, que tienen una medida de 30x30cm y 3mm de grosor.
Este remix permite que el espejo quede sujeto por los cuatro costados, dejando el cristal sujeto. Por otra parte he eliminado el reborde que sobresale por la parte superior, para evitar colisiones con el fusor cuando se acerca a las esquinas.

I found a cllip design to attach a 30x30 crystal to the tornado bed: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2722668
I bought a pack of 4 LOTS mirrors in Ikea, which measure 30x30cm and 3mm thick.
This remix allows the mirror is clamped on all four sides, leaving the glass subject. Moreover I have removed the overhanging lip at the top, to avoid collisions with the fuser when approaching the corners.

ADJUSTABLE PHONE & TABLET STAND

  • Tiltable
  • Print-in-place
  • No screws needed

While most phone / tablet stand provide a single, static position only, this adjustable phone and tablet stand lets you choose your preferred tilt angle. The included phone stand is designed to hold phones up to 6", while the included tablet stand is designed for phones or tablets up to 8".

PRINTING:

  • Use a raft for best heatbed adhesion

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Just for fun... 'Skateboardz' are one piece prints of a skateboard with moving wheels. They make a fun little print with moving parts plus you can have lots of fun with them by flicking and flipping them...so a great fidget toy as well!

On a well set up, precise / accurate PLA machine this is a small and easy print. The parts are all very thin so print with high infill for strength... and it will still only use about 10gm of filament.

'Skateboardz' can be printed in you favourite color... and scaled up if you want. However, scaling down much may result in the axles fusing so the wheels won't turn. At standard scale 'Skateboardz' are 100mm in length.

Please refer to the images and print settings / instructions for additional information... and post images of your Skateboardz for other members to see... particularly if you've decorated them in a special way and / or of them doing some amazing stunts!

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

PLA / 2 Shells / 50% infill for strength... it still won't use much filament!

Notes:

Raft is recommended for good build plate adhesion as this is printed on its side and the contact area with the build plate is minimal

No support required... and do not use automated support.

Free the wheels / axle...

If necessary gently wiggle the wheels and push them back / forth sideways to break the axles free. A quick spray of a light lubricant on the moving / contact surfaces will help the wheels spin more freely.

title: Hopper car body, for Marklin hobby range car chassis

description.text:
Hopper body for H0 scale model railroad car. Compatible with Marklin/Trix hobby range of car chassis, as well as the printable chassis I made before.

This is a purely imaginary car roughly based on the 4-axle grain hoppers that are available as a model. I made this shape because it is not commercially available for this type of chassis.

2 versions have been included:

  • one with the snap joint to mount on an original Marklin system chassis. This is more difficult to print.
  • one with a flat bottom, intended for screw mounting or glueing. easier to print. matches the chassis I designed

Use 2mmx5 self tapping screws with large collar (recommended) or M2x5mm size screws for mounting.

5 cavities for M6 size nuts are provided to be able to add additional weight.

Picture shows it with my chassis, check my other things to get it as well! Only the grey colored part is included here. I added an assembled 3D model for use in thingyviewer, this one is not for printing.

title: GuideCut - a guided Utility-Knife to trim paper, foil etc. at edges

description.text:
I build this this tool to help trimming straight edges on self-adhesive foil. But I guess you can use it in many ways when cutting alongside an edge is required.

The basic design is made for standard trapezoid blades, but I'm happy to provide different adapters for different blade types.

The blade is wedged securely in between the two holder parts.
This assembly is then put in the guide, and held together at the same time.

Carefully place the blade-holder in any of the slots in the guide to adjust spaceing towards the guide. Be very careful when removing the blade!

When cutting adjust the cutting depth with very slight pressure on the blade.

Surely you know but still:
Please be careful when assembling & cutting & adjusting - these blades are darn sharp and can injure you badly.

Notes:

I printed it with 2 - 3 perimeters and 0.24mm layer height. and 100% Infill.
In standard PLA plastic.

The parts don't require any support or special treatment.

Depending on your Printer you might need to clean some edges so the parts snap together well. The Blade must not be forced into the assembly - it should fit just easy. If it doesn't check your print settings or contact me - don't fiddle with those sharp blades.

title: Festool vacuum adapter for Felder combination machine (96,5mm)

description.text:
On the Festool side I plug my hose coming from my Festool vacuum cleaner.
I introduce the 96.5mm side on my woodworking combination machine.
Due to the edge on the Festool side dusts are not blocked in the adapter.
The slope on the 96.5mm side is sufficient for keeping a decent air flow.

I printed it on a Formlabs Form2 with FLGPGR03 resin (6 h 18 min / 100 µm / 86.4 mL). It gave a very good result.

The Catia V5-6R2012 source file is for someone who wants to remix this.
There is also a STEP file exported from Catia but you will lose many features.
Please share your work.

description.text:
Medieval Spear

This is part of a full set off weapons with the same theme;

  • Medieval Axe => https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2764517
  • Medieval Sword => https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2757290

Components (9);

  • Printed parts (6)
    o Spear Tip 1
    o Spear Tip 2
    o Ring (2x)
    o Pommel
    o Spear Head
  • Standard components (3)
    o PVC pipe diameter 32mm length ±1.34m (52.755 inch)
    o 2 Wooden dowels 8mm x 35mm

The 2 dowels are used to connect the two pieces of the spear tip together (you could choose print components instead of using the wooden dowels). The dowels actually worked out great, they made for an excellent connection between the 2 pieces.

Pvc pipe will function as grip. You can choose the length of the pvc pipe as you like. I went for a length of ±1.34m (52.755 inch) pipe for the spear to give a total length of 1.8 metre (70.866 inch).

• Micro propellers with 3, 4 and 5 blades
  • 1mm hole - for : 7x20mm 8x20mm 8.5x20mm brushed motors (and some other with 1mm shaft)
  • Size : 55mm in diameter

Not sure about this yet. It prints OK and seems to work, but whether it is any improvement over my earlier coupler is debatable.

The point of the design is to reduce stress on the coupler and the threaded rod in the (many) cases where the rods aren't straight. If anyone tries this I'd really like to know if it is any good or not. For me I seem to have a smoother z than when using the rigid coupler, but as yet I only have this one one side - will print the other side out later (with the one side fitted) and we'll see.

Each part requires an M3 nut to be placed in the recess on the base and an M3 bolt which holds the nut and then presses against either the motor shaft (bottom piece) of the thin section of the threaded rod (top piece). The two parts of the linkage are supposed to be connected by threading an M2 bolt through the hole in the tines.

print_settings.Notes:: The holes are filled by the tolerance of the machine but since it is drilled when put into the machine, at first I will try it this way, if I see that it is not boring and the coffee does not come out I will design them bigger.

title: tapa capsula nespresso (Nespresso cap caps) para modelo www.thingiverse.com/thing:2376494

description.text:
Hice la capsula www.thingiverse.com/thing:2376494, y para esta he diseñado la tapa. Como las tolerancias en 0.2, que son las que he aprendido a dominar, son diferentes al trabajar en 0.1, la tapa ha quedado con un poco de holgura, así que le he puesto un poco de cinta adhesiva alrededor. Cuando la pruebe en la máquina, haré las correcciones oportunas para afinar la tapa. Ya la tengo preparada rellena de café para probarla mañana en el trabajo. He dejado el fichero en formato Freecad para que lo modifiquéis a gusto.

Traducción Google:
I made the capsule www.thingiverse.com/thing:2376494, and for this I designed the cap. As the tolerances in 0.2, which are the ones I have learned to master, are different when working in 0.1, the lid has been left with a bit of slack, so I have put a bit of tape around it. When I try it on the machine, I will make the appropriate corrections to refine the lid. I already have it ready filled with coffee to try it tomorrow at work. I have left the file in Freecad format so you can modify it to your liking.

description.text:
See the Standard version of this case here (Standard Wifi antenna):
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2778278

This is a compact and slim case for the Orange Pi Lite.
It has a swivel WiFi antenna that folds to the back whenever needed for storage and transportation.
It'll even fit inside the box that the OPi Lite came in!

It's a passively cooled case with access to GPIO pins by removing the plastic protection.

It's build for low/med performance, running constantly at 100% load may not be a good idea due to being passively cooled. Should not be worse than running the card naked though.
For use with OctoPrint, CPU temp average at ~40°-50°C.

4 pcs M3x12 insex screws
4 pcs M3 nuts

[Electronic parts needed]
Orange Pi Lite
Orange Pi Heatsinks
RP-SMA Antenna Adapter

description.text:
This is a more visible and 3D version of catan's number scheme. Especially good for large boards, 3D sets, and those pesky 6-versus-9 mixups.

The base is 1 inch around, which is the same size as a standard number token in catan, which should render this compatible with anything that uses regular number tokens.

The STL included is a set of all number tokens that come with a basic set (two 12's, two 2's, and 3 of everything else). You can generate any number token you want, but do make sure to include the right number of pips.

The colors were added using acrylic paints. However, if you have a multi-extruder setup, it shouldn't be too hard to modify the SCAD files to give you the appropriate output.

comments.text: I printed it. mounted it on an arrow and got a slight whistle if any noise at all. no disrespect, great design, great print, just little noise :)
comments.author: farrellsprops

comments.text: Can a nock be made to whistle?
comments.author: kresty

comments.text: I imagine so; although almost all of the ones I looked into had the whistler piece on the front end of the arrow... I was working on another version that would wrap around the arrow near the end of the nock or just above the tip; however that would require different setting diameter depending on the arrow used (see comment from an earlier ideation)... I also tried an few tests modifying the fletching/vanes in a few ways by cutting or hole-punching but nothing was quite as effective;  it's possible that one could build a whistler piece that fits just under the arrow vanes without causing too much imbalance/weight addition to the end of the arrow... an extended knock with the whistle slots/holes built into the hollow portion of the nock might work; you may not need much, take a look at whistler nerf darts and the concept could be applied without creating a large/lengthy piece.
comments.author: kresty

comments.text: My thinking would be that it'd be way easier to print the nock end and have it not destroy itself :)  I might try that if I get really bored one day.
comments.author: onebitpixel

comments.text: sure thing; I might work on one that mounts under the vanes; it wouldn't be as simple as swapping out a nock though; unless it was one that wrapped around the arrow in a snap fit model...
comments.author: kresty

comments.text: Presumably this needs to be made of metal to avoid becoming a one-shot wonder?
comments.author: vik

comments.text: yeah, metal... most of these are turn formed/cast from aluminum or in stainless steel/iron. I've built one before using a simple metal lathe.  I did an ABS print on this particular model and the walls are a little thin, if I were to build it with ABS then I will probably remodel it with thicker walls and larger/lonfer cavity.  I have seen the ones made from antiperspirant rolls and I might make something along that line next; I was originally trying to build a whistler in two parts that could be attached to an existing arrow shaft a few inches from the arrow tip insert, wrapping around the shaft in two parts; however depending on draw length it could get in the way of the bow shelf or limit full draw. The other issue was depending on how it was fixed (compression fit, screw or glue) to the shaft it had the potential to slide after release or when the arrow hit the target and slide down the length of the shaft towards the vains...  thanks for the comments!
comments.author: vik

description.text:
This spool holder was designed to recycle axles and bearings found inside of rollerblades.

  2. Assemble wheels the same way you'd assemble and attach a wheel to an inline skate boot.

author: MarvinNauendorff

description.text: Use Slicer for this model.

Take 4 solid squares with unit side length and an height of 2/3. If you connect them at their horizontal or vertical faces you get 18 different pieces, which can be used to construct a lot of figures. Since the height of 3 squares is equal to the width of two squares square faces and rectangular faces can touch in the constructions.
Sometimes the pieces were turned to prevent overhanging parts and to get the smaller rectangular faces at the top.

...in a 3 part 3d printed grip enclosure.

runs off anything between 12v upto 26v (so 3s-6s), of course the higher the voltage the better the speed but generally the torques pretty good even on a 3s with a simple on-off flip switch at the back.

printed it in PLA (which I didnt expect to last long if the motor got hot) but it proved sturdy enough to last and hasnt showed any signs of breakage so far so even the most basic printer should be able to make this.

been a trusted and useful companion out in the field and on the benchtop and I expect it'll still be around for many moons to come

author: PedaBot

title: 3DRC 1/24 AWD Drift car
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The latest 3DRC vehicle! It's a small, reasonably easy to print drift car with a realistic body.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S7eIB1OpTlw

More detailed S14 Zenki body available here: https://cults3d.com/en/3d-model/various/zenki-s14-240sx-body-for-3drc-1-24-drift-car

All parts (except tyres) can be printed in PLA. I used rigid.ink flexi PLA for the tyres but any flexible filament can be used.

Printed in high quality rigid.ink filament - see their filament range and comparison here:
https://rigid.ink/pages/filament-comparison-guide

Features:
All wheel drive-makes drifting fun and easy
Simple, durable construction
Realistic body inspired by the Nissan 240sx
Drivetrain runs on ball bearings

Extra parts:
M3 bolts and 3mm shaft (listed in assembly guide)
1304 outrunner motor (I used this one: https://hobbyking.com/en_us/3100kv.html but any with a similar kv should work)
10 amp brushless car esc
4.4g servo (https://hobbyking.com/en_us/turnigytm-tgy-1440a-analog-servo-v2-0-8kg-0-10sec-4-4g.html)
Small (350ish mAh) 2s LiPo battery - fits in rear bumper
2ch radio system (2.4ghz recommended)

I can print any part of this for a small fee - PM me if you need part of it printing and can't do it yourself.

Vote here on what to make next:
http://www.strawpoll.me/14947301
(or message me if you have any other interesting ideas), the winning idea will be released on Cults3d once it is finished.
Designed in Fusion 360

description.text:
I believe that the GT2560 board is one of the best boards if you would like to build your own printer. It's compact, well integrated and not too expensive. Also it supports most needs and has a well made layout.

So I decided to build a universal housing that holds the board, a graphical smart controller and is easy to print. I've also payed attention that board set-up and installation is as easy as possible. This is guaranteed by using single plates that can be removed individually and give you best access to the board and it's components. In addition I decided to use an external power supply to be as flexible as possible.

Currently the layout is designed for a RepRap printer without heated bed. But of course you can add a heated bed easily - just make sure your power supply is strong enough.

Parts you need:

  • GT2560 controller board
  • Full Graphic Smart Controller (RepRapDiscount)
  • 12V/10A external power supply
  • 12V 60mm Fan (e.g Noise Blocker XR2)
  • D-Sub 15 & D-Sub25 connector
  • Power Switch (DS 059 SW)
  • DC panel jack (e.g. DC-EBU 072339)
  • 4x 3/10mm screws
  • 14x 3/10mm countersunk screws (10mm)
  • 4x 3mm nuts (for the fan)
  • 3 cable ties
  • and of course the printed parts of this Thing :)

Assembly: Please refer to Instructions.pdf

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

When using ABS add ABS slurry to your glass plate so you get a smooth and flat finish.
Sanded the surfaces and painted mate black.

Designed in 123D Design from Autocad.
Front plate needed a lot of trial and error since most dimensions you can find in the web are wrong.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed these slowly to get the best threading without any supports.  The design on Cap2 can be printed without support.  It gives a cool surface finish to the recessed rings.

description.text:
Meet Nester, the nesting jar/container. Great for storing your medicine, change, herbals, supplements, whatever you can put in the individual container sections. It's the first size, but the second version. I'm already working on some improvements for the new version that's coming soon.

This guy prints great without supports, but make sure you print slightly slower and have good cooling (Or, at least this is for my Frankenstein of a printer). I made the thread tolerance pretty tight, so hopefully this will work on other printers. The inside of the lid is formed to the top of the inner container outline. This helps to ensure nothing will spill over from one compartment to the next should the jar drop.

I posted two lids for this. The Cap1 is the original lid, but for some reason doesn't print clean on the outside for me. I made another cap without any outside rim features, and it seemed to print better. It's probably just my printer. The Cap2 interior seal/form (The part that meets the interior container) comes a little farther down on the sides. Hopefully the future Cap3 will be a successful blend of both (Or just another new design).

You might need to clean up any extra plastic or elephant-foot issues as the interior containers are pretty tight in tolerance as well. Mine displace air when they are pushed in, but they do not get stuck. You might need to work them around a little bit to break things in.

I put a notch on the bottom of the jar so it matters not which order the inner containers are put back in. I'm working on different sizes and layouts for the containers, so stay tuned for more!

Let me know if you have any questions, thanks!

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I printed these slowly to get the best threading without any supports. The design on Cap2 can be printed without support. It gives a cool surface finish to the recessed rings.
Just make sure to clean any extra plastic at the outside base of the interior jars. They fit tight, so might bind if the walls are not perfectly straight.

author: COLOR3DJP

description.text:
Hi all, I designed a 3 part wall mounted shelving arm.

It takes 3/4 inch thick, 6 inch wide panels as the main shelf and can be mounted either on dry walls or concrete walls using 2 3/16 inch screws. Make sure you get a screw length thats long enough to pass thru the mount and into the wall.

Assembly is pretty straight forward.
Measure, mark and drill your top hole location.
Attach one screw with the mounting part and make sure it's level before marking the next hole. You can do this just to be precise. But if you're in a hurry you can mark the bottom hole 30mm from the top. Screw and tighten everything up!
*Glue the 2 arms together and slide it on the mounting part and you're done! (The tricky part would be leveling the two mounts together, and you need to cut a little square piece of the top panel you're attaching so that it remains flush with the arms)

*I recommend 2 arms for every 2-2.5ft of shelving length. This is measured outisde-outside of each mount.
And the load it can carry will depend on the material you're using and you're personal infill settings.
I recommend a 100% infill if you're planning on putting heavy stuff

description.text:
Rooster TBS style SMA mount at 90 degrees (no antenna tubes on this one). I have personally printed it, and did not like the shortness of the SMA plug. Thickness of the 3d part hole is 1.5mm, anything greater and antenna does not screw down fully, but might be just a tad too thin for my liking, and could rip out the SMA in a crash.

Personally, I chopped off my TBS style and soldered on a standard style to use the other mounts I listed. Much better "bite" when tightening it to the print.

Willing to do a 45, if demand is high enough, but want to focus on some other ideas for the rooster.

Had a grinding bearing on the original pulley and noticed the pulley was slanted as well, new pulley and mounted using this part and no matter how much tension is on the belt the pulley spins freely and level with the belt path

description.text:
Ever had a problem with filament looping around your center pin of your REEL holder? That happens if unwinding a reel happens in an uncontrolled/uneven way.
My design holds the reel in between two conical center whereof the back cone has two GLACIER bearings. D=18d=16L=16
The front and rear cone makes it possible to receive reels with ID of 52 to 58.
The C-Washer makes quick Reel changes possible.
The back-cone is hold by a sturdy support block that is bolted down on my printers
Furthermore by using a filament guide, the filament comes always centered from my reel.
It makes me sleep on one ear again.

author: jvalencia

description.text:
These are used to protect cables for the 3D printer and make things neater when running cables through 40x40 extrusion.  it routes the cable in the extrusion out through flexible 16mm cable management available at a hardware store (Bunnings here in Australia).  Is designed so it can slip over existing cable and if you use the split cable management you won't need to disconnect anything.   
I'll be adding a few other different ones as I design them for my Felix Printer, but should work for just about any that uses 40x40 aluminium extrusion
They will need support as I print them face down, but have a play around and your mileage may vary.

This thing consists of everything needed to setup a Pozyx UWB testbed without any great effort. A tag is supposed not to be used in conjunction with an Arduino, but most likely connected to a computer via serial port.

The casing for tags provides protection while doing localization experiments. Anchors are assumed to be fixed most of the time, therefore the - somewhat geometric - frame is kept together with cable ties making it highly convertible for different places of installation.

For one casing you need:

  • 2x tag-side
  • 2x tag-conn
  • 2x tag-pin
  • 4x 2.5 mm screws

For one frame placing an anchor upright - as shown in the image - you need:

  • 1x anchor-O
  • 2x anchor-T
  • 2x anchor-X
  • 6x cable ties

author: 3dball

description.text:
Thanks mayaway for creating the original.

Changed a couple of things, adding an LED that's connected to the echo pin (with a current limiter in series). It will pulse the same length of time as the echo pin is pulled high, so short distance pings will produce a very short blip on the LED. Oscilloscope screenshots are of the echo pulse.

The other way to add an LED is to let the microcontroller drive it; that way you're not dependent on the echo time. I only have 4 wires in the cable (used for Vcc, Gnd, Trig and Echo), so this is the most straightforward way, though it's possible to make the Trig and Echo share the same wire (google it).

Added a little bit of depth to accommodate the extra wiring, and little slots to use zip strips for mounting.

Part of my Garage home automation project,
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2771892

author: ZekeAsakura

description.text:
Cover for a Zippo style lighter, Meant to cover the lighter case, as i dont know if the plastic will hold up to the fuel. Can leave plain to protect your current metal case, or you can add an image to it to spiff it up a bit.
Cover dimensions : X: 1.5cm (15mm) Y: 4.5cm (45mm) Z: 6.4cm (64mm)
Internal dimensions: X: 1.3cm (13mm) Y: 3.9cm(39mm) Z: 5.5cm (55mm) Hinges Are 4mm x 4mm x 4mm , With a 3mm inner diameter. Hinge pin varies from 2mm - 3mm *Note: This is a test file, as i haven't printed it yet, Waiting on a replacement hot end. The case cover should fit snug-ly, however, the Hinge is custom designed, and I do not know for a fact that it will work right. If anyones able to print this to test it Feedback would be wonderful, Otherwise i'll update in a week or so once the new hot end comes in.

This was made by measuring a zippo, and creating a cube for the top and bottom, then making a solid cube the volume of both cubes. then i scaled up the top and bottom cubes, and subtracted the solid cube from the 2 seperate cubes, creating a hollow space inside for the zippo to fit.
The hinge is a custom design, with 2 loops on a bridge connected to the top half, and one loop on a bridge connected to the bottom half, with a pin going through all 3 loops. The pin started as a cylinder, which i loop cut on the outsides of the middle loop, and scaled up the outsides of it to create 2 cones, connecting to the 2 outside loops locking it in place, creating an hourglass shape within the loops.
The loops and bridges were unioned together using Boolean Modifiers , as opposed to joining, so that there weren't excess vertices, keeping print time, material, and slicing time to a minimum.

description.text:
Design trophy figure for the top of a trophy. Great to recognize outstanding student designs. I used this as an example for a student project on incorporating fastners into a 3D printed part. The students all made their own trophy figures with similar captured nuts.

Trophy figure stands 90mm (3.5 inches) tall. Works great with a wooden base or could be used to replace a figure on the top of another trophy.

0.3mm layers or finer

yes

Notes:

Rotate +280 degrees (or -80 degrees) about X axis to lay the back surface flat on the bed as shown in the screenshots. Prints well with no supports.

Spray paint all over, brush the details and clearcoat the finished part. Assemble with a 1/4-20 nut in the slot and a 1/4-20 machine screw through a base.

Drill a little counterbore at the bottom of the base to hide the head of the screw.

The screw can insert between 10 and 18mm (about 3/8" to 11/16") into the part, so pay attention to the length of your screw. A 1" long screw through 1/2" (13mm) base material works well.

You can add sections of PVC or wood with a 5/16 hole through it to make the trophy taller.

Or use standard trophy parts.

The fasteners are sized to fit standard 1/4-20 trophy threaded rod and couplings. If you want to use this to replace the top of another trophy it works great.

title: 3d printer hepa filter holmes aer1 filter with carbon pre-filter

description.text:
Using the following fan:

https://www.digikey.com/short/qj7fmv

Holmes filter is this one:

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00DWHVE62/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

And then any activated carbon pre-filter will do. You'll need to cut it to size, as I couldn't fine anything stock that would fit.

I HATE PRINT SUPPORT, SO..... NO PRINT SUPPORT REQUIRED.

There are three model here but you only need one. If you're printer will print larger than 250mm then you can print the one piece. Small flange goes on the bed. If not you'll need the two piece. I tried the one symmetrical one piece but my case was in the way and so I had to make the offset one. Pre-filter cage just snaps onto the filter. #6 screws hold it together and I used some light caulk to seal the joints. The slide gate I designed is also located on thingiverse. You'll need to print 8 of the clips.

Elbows do not need support if printed in the correct orientation either. There are two elbows . One is symmetrical and short and the other has one side extended an inch or so. Use which ever ones fits with your case. ALL FLANGES ARE COMPATIBLE WITH AN 80MM FAN.

The tables I used for my enclosure are a couple of inches larger than the Ikea Lack tables, so be aware of that when building to make sure you have the proper clearance. A lack table enclosure should work, but it's going to be tight depending on how you mount everything.

I have a particle counter and from what it picks up there is no change in particle count when I print, which is a good thing.

Filter was inspired by another AER1 filter on thingiverse, although mine is an original design and not a remix / modification of that one.
